He has talked about 'guiding principles' that have already been agreed upon and an agreement that seems 'attainable' if both sides put diplomacy ahead of threats after rounds in Geneva and Oman in the past few weeks. Iranian state media used to often call the US the 'Great Satan,' but now they report on US policies in a more fair way. Ali Khamenei, the Supreme Leader, has even let the foreign ministry look into options without the usual loud protests.

This isn't a sudden change in beliefs. It's a cold, hard calculation made by a religious group that is having a hard time staying alive in the long run. The leaders of the Islamic Republic know that another round of open war could be deadly because the country has already been hit with blows that would have killed weaker governments.
Why Military Facts Are Important

The war in June caused deep wounds. Israeli and American strikes damaged several air defense batteries, messed up command chains, and stopped Iran's nuclear development, but it's still not clear how much. Independent evaluations show that the damage lasted months, maybe even years, instead of permanently destroying the sites. However, U.S. officials say the sites were 'obliterated.' In any case, Tehran saw the destruction of its most important strategic assets without much restriction. Being alone won't give us the time, money, or space we need to rebuild those layered defenses, find new leaders, and get our enrichment capabilities back.

Senior IRGC officials who used to act like they were unbeatable now have to deal with the fact that Iran's regular military capabilities were made public. The government knows that fighting another war head-on would be suicide, especially since the U.S. military is currently sending fighter jets, carriers, and missile defenses to the Gulf.
An economy that is falling apart and people who are worried

The war's aftermath hurt an already fragile economy even more. Inflation was between 40 and 50 percent until late 2025. Some sources said that food prices had gone up as much as 72 percent a year. When the rial fell to an all-time low of more than 1.4 million to the dollar by early 2026, it caused protests all over the country that started on December 28, 2025, and quickly spread to all 31 provinces. Because there wasn't enough gas, there were power outages, and the shelves were empty, regular Iranians went to the streets, shopkeepers closed bazaars, and workers quit their jobs. Reports say that thousands were killed or arrested because of the government's harsh response. The crackdown seemed to restore order on the surface, but the anger is still there.

There have also been years of sanctions, frozen foreign assets worth tens of billions, young unemployment that is thought to be close to 40%, and the effects of the war on oil exports and the Tehran stock market, which fell sharply. The leaders of the Revolutionary Guard and the religious elite can see the writing on the wall: more isolation could lead to more unrest, a brain drain, and even splits within their own ranks. From this point of view, diplomacy is not a sign of weakness but an economic oxygen mask.
A Smaller Regional Impact

It looks like Iran's famous 'Axis of Resistance' is having a hard time. Hezbollah in Lebanon had to change its position after losing a lot of ground and feeling pressure from Israel. When Bashar al-Assad fell in Syria, important supply routes were cut off. Houthi operations in Yemen are still going on, even though there are fewer ways for Iran to send money. Tehran doesn't have much money left, so it has cut back on funding for its proxies. Neither China nor Russia has shown a strong desire to pour resources into a sinking ship because they have their own goals and are not very willing to break Western sanctions on Iran's behalf.

Tehran wants to talk to Washington to ease the pressure on its remaining allies, buy time to reorganize, and maybe even create a new balance of power in the region where it doesn't always have to be on the defensive.
Being realistic and not giving up

Araghchi and his team are careful with their words. They don't call the outreach 'surrender,' but 'pragmatic engagement' based on common interests and regional stability. Western diplomats always hear the same thing from Tehran: it wants the sanctions lifted so that it can fix its economy, avoid more military retaliation, and gain some bargaining power in the future. One way to buy time is to get some space now so you can rebuild later.

Iranian officials still won't talk about ballistic missiles or proxy operations in the talks that are going on, and they still say they have the 'right' to enrich uranium for peaceful purposes. But there is a clear difference from the loud rejection of the past. Just by being at the Geneva table, talking about guiding principles and making frameworks, they have changed.
Washington's Hard Choice

This is a big problem for the Trump administration. Getting back in touch could stop Iran's nuclear development, cool down the region, and maybe even lead to the release of prisoners or other steps to build trust. Critics say it could make the same mistakes as the 2015 JCPOA, scare Israel and its Gulf allies, and give a government that is still accused of destabilizing the region more power.

Some people say that the U.S. red lines include verifiable enrichment limits (some say they should be zero), less violence by proxies, and verifiable compliance. Israel is worried because it doesn't want any deal that will give Iran the ability to make nuclear weapons or let Hezbollah get more weapons. The governments of the Gulf need real limits on Iran's interference and unbreakable security guarantees. Internal U.S. politics and the uncertainty surrounding the 2024 election cycle add another layer of complexity.

Richard Haass, a former president of the Council on Foreign Relations, has called this 'one of the most delicate moments in U.S.-Iran relations since 2015.' Both sides are tired in their own ways. Tehran is weaker but can still threaten the Strait of Hormuz, use proxies, and have missiles. Washington, on the other hand, is in charge of the military but doesn't want a long war.
A Small Chance for Big Change

There are many examples in history of how mutual vulnerability can open doors that strength had closed. Iran's current overtures show weakness instead of strength, as they realize that their old strategy of proxy war and defiance is no longer working. In the next few weeks, the details that are worked out will determine whether this leads to real, verifiable agreements or just another tactical pause.

The stakes for the whole Middle East couldn't be higher. A real de-escalation could lead to restructuring alliances, stabilizing energy markets, and lowering the risk of a larger conflict. But if the talks break down because the parties don't trust each other, the area could go back to war sooner than anyone wants.

We don't think that Iran's revolutionary philosophy will come to an end. The clerical system has always been best at adapting to stay alive. The question now is whether Washington and its allies in the region can use their own smart diplomacy to respond to that pragmatism. In geopolitics, this kind of thing doesn't happen very often. The way they are treated will have an effect for a long time.

geo-politics.metaTitle: Indonesia's Bold BRICS Join Reshapes Global South Strategy
geo-politics.metaDescription: Indonesia under Prabowo advances bebas-aktif policy by joining BRICS in 2025, boosting ties with China, reducing dollar reliance, and balancing US relations through pragmatic diplomacy and diversified finance.
geo-politics.title: Indonesia's BRICS Entry & De-Dollarization Strategy Reshapes Geopolitics
geo-politics.excerpt: Indonesia is quietly rewriting the rules of its place in the world, and the changes happening right now could reshape Southeast Asia and the broader Global South for years to come.
geo-politics.imageAlt: Indonesian President speaking at international summit with national flag displayed, representing Indonesia’s BRICS membership and multi-alignment foreign policy strategy

content.text: Indonesia is quietly rewriting the rules of its place in the world, and the changes happening right now could reshape Southeast Asia and the broader Global South for years to come. What we’re seeing isn’t a sudden U-turn—it’s the natural evolution of a country that has always prized independence but is now facing a much more complicated global stage. With fresh emphasis on reducing dollar dependence, stepping deeper into BRICS, building economic ties in every direction, and speaking up louder for developing nations, Jakarta is carving out real strategic space for itself.

At the core of everything remains the old guiding star: bebas-aktif, or “free and active.” For more than seven decades this principle has kept Indonesia out of formal military alliances, away from picking sides in great-power fights, and focused on whatever actually serves its 280-million-strong population. Think back to the Cold War—Indonesia didn’t join SEATO or the Soviet bloc. It stayed non-aligned and active in the Non-Aligned Movement. That same spirit is still there, but today it looks different because the world looks different. Great-power rivalry is back, supply chains are fragile, and the U.S. dollar’s dominance suddenly feels less automatic than it did ten years ago.

The shift became impossible to ignore during the Russia-Ukraine war. When Western capitals demanded that every G20 member freeze out Moscow, then-President Joko Widodo simply refused. Indonesia’s 2022 G20 presidency in Bali became a masterclass in stubborn neutrality. Jokowi personally visited Kyiv and Moscow, kept dialogue channels open, and even extended an invitation to Vladimir Putin for the summit. The message was blunt: isolation solves nothing; talking might. That single decision told the world Jakarta would not be pressured into choosing camps, no matter how loud the calls from Washington or Brussels.

President Prabowo Subianto, who took office in late 2024 after a decisive election victory, has kept that balancing DNA but added his own pragmatic muscle. A former special forces commander and defense minister, Prabowo understands power realities better than most. Within weeks of being sworn in he made back-to-back visits to Beijing and Washington—deliberately, visibly, and without apology. The choreography was the point: engage both giants, let neither own you.

The Washington trip was especially telling. Donald Trump’s second term had barely started when new tariff threats hit Indonesian exports—up to 32 percent on key goods. Many observers expected fireworks. Instead, Prabowo’s team sat down and cut a practical deal. Tariffs dropped to 19 percent. In exchange, Indonesia committed to buying more than $4 billion in U.S. liquefied natural gas, soybeans, other agricultural products, and Boeing aircraft. It was classic transactional diplomacy—painful concessions avoided, mutual economic interests protected, and nobody lost face.

At almost the same time, the China relationship was moving into overdrive. Beijing rolled out $10 billion in fresh investment commitments covering everything from nickel processing plants to high-speed rail extensions and renewable energy. Bilateral trade already sits at around $135 billion annually. For a country hungry to upgrade its infrastructure and move up the value chain in electric vehicles and batteries, these numbers are game-changing. Prabowo has shown he can keep the economic tap wide open with China while still locking in important American purchases. That’s not fence-sitting; it’s sophisticated multi-vector statecraft.

Then came the headline that really turned heads: Indonesia formally joined BRICS in January 2025. Foreign Minister Sugiono called it a natural next step for a country that refuses to be a passive spectator in global affairs. BRICS—now much larger than the original Brazil-Russia-India-China-South Africa core—gives Indonesia a seat at a table where the Global South actually sets part of the agenda. It’s a platform to push for fairer trade rules, alternative development finance, technology sharing, and yes, ways to slowly reduce reliance on Western-dominated financial systems.

Sugiono put it plainly: BRICS lets Indonesia amplify middle-power diplomacy, strengthen ties with other emerging giants, and gain leverage when negotiating with traditional partners. It also slots neatly into Indonesia’s historic role in the Non-Aligned Movement, just updated for 2025 realities where multipolarity is no longer a theory—it’s daily life.

The financial side of this story is equally fascinating. Bank Indonesia has quietly shifted more of its foreign-exchange operations toward the Chinese yuan, with the Japanese yen coming next. Senior Deputy Governor Destry Damayanti explained the logic in straightforward terms: settling trade directly in partner currencies takes pressure off the dollar and builds a healthier, more resilient domestic financial ecosystem. This isn’t revolutionary rhetoric; it’s practical risk management.

Complementing that move, Indonesia committed $1 billion to the BRICS New Development Bank. The NDB already finances infrastructure across the Global South without the policy-conditionality baggage that often comes with IMF or World Bank loans. Jakarta sees it as a hedge and an opportunity—more money for ports, roads, and green projects, plus stronger political ties with fellow emerging economies.

These steps build on groundwork laid years earlier. Since 2021 Indonesia has expanded local-currency settlement arrangements, especially with China. By July 2025 more than $6 billion in bilateral trade had been settled directly in yuan and rupiah. Economic Affairs Minister Airlangga Hartarto summed up the philosophy: “This is about building financial resilience and protecting our economic sovereignty in a volatile world.”

Let’s put some hard numbers on the table, because they tell the story better than slogans:
• $1 billion invested in the BRICS New Development Bank • $135 billion in annual trade with China (2024 figure) • More than $4 billion in new U.S. purchases secured under the tariff deal • Over $6 billion in yuan-rupiah transactions since the local-currency framework expanded • $10 billion in fresh Chinese investment commitments • U.S. tariffs successfully negotiated down from 32 % to 19 %

Taken together, these moves paint a clear picture. Indonesia is not pivoting away from the United States or the West. It is simply refusing to depend on any single partner or currency. Former Ambassador Dr. Rizal Sukma captured the thinking perfectly: “This is bebas-aktif for the 21st century—strategic autonomy through diversification, not isolation or blind alignment.”

Of course, walking this tightrope isn’t easy. South China Sea tensions continue, U.S. expectations on regional security remain high, and domestic critics sometimes ask whether closer BRICS ties could complicate relations with traditional donors. Yet Prabowo’s early record suggests a leader comfortable with complexity. He understands that Indonesia’s size—fourth most populous country, third-largest democracy, largest Muslim-majority nation—gives it natural weight. The goal is to use that weight wisely.

Looking ahead, Indonesia’s choices will echo far beyond its archipelago. Other middle powers in the Global South are watching closely. If Jakarta can deliver tangible development gains through BRICS and diversified finance while keeping solid ties with Washington, it will offer a practical model for the rest of the developing world. As foreign-policy scholar Dr. Dewi Fortuna Anwar recently observed, what we’re seeing is not a minor adjustment but the rise of Indonesia as a confident actor that wants to help write the rules of the new international order instead of simply following them.

The coming months will test how smoothly this multi-layered strategy can be implemented—especially as BRICS meetings intensify and global trade tensions ebb and flow. One thing already feels certain: the old image of Indonesia as a passive regional player is gone. In its place stands a more assertive, economically pragmatic nation determined to shape its own destiny in an age of renewed great-power competition. The world, whether it likes it or not, will have to adjust to a bolder Jakarta.

geo-politics.metaTitle: US Warns China Massively Expanding Nuclear Arsenal
geo-politics.metaDescription: US accuses China of rapid, opaque nuclear buildup amid New START expiry; Beijing rejects claims as smears, refuses trilateral talks; fears grow of new global arms race.
geo-politics.title: US Accuses China of Massively Expanding Nuclear Arsenal Amid Fears of New Arms Race
geo-politics.excerpt: With New START expired, US claims China is rapidly growing its nuclear forces without transparency; Beijing denies arms race intent and rejects joining US-Russia talks.
geo-politics.imageAlt: Chinese military parade displaying multiple rocket launcher or missile systems, highlighting nuclear and strategic capabilities

content.text: The current date is February 25, 2026. The US has stepped up its criticism of China, saying that Beijing is quickly building up its nuclear weapons, which has raised fears of a new arms race. This comes just after the New START agreement, which was the last major nuclear weapons deal between the US and Russia, two of the world's most powerful countries, ended earlier this month. Beijing is strongly against Washington's request for a new agreement that includes China. It says the accusations are false and that it doesn't want to be part of such a race.

Christopher Yeaw, the U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation, made it very clear in a speech at the Geneva Conference on Disarmament. "China has deliberately and without restraint massively expanded its nuclear arsenal without transparency or any indication of China's intent or end point," Yeaw said. He criticized the previous New START as being out of date and flawed because it didn't take into account what he called China's "unprecedented, deliberate, rapid, and opaque" nuclear expansion. He is not holding back when he says that Beijing is avoiding responsibility while building up its military.

China acted quickly and decisively. At the same meeting, Ambassador Shen Jian hit back, saying that his country "strongly opposes the constant distortion and smearing of its nuclear policy by some countries." He stressed that "China will not engage in any nuclear arms race with any country." " According to groups like the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN), Shen said that the U.S. and Russian arsenals, which together have more than 5,000 warheads, are much better than China's. He then said, "It is not fair, reasonable, or realistic to expect China to take part in the so-called trilateral talks." This ended the chance of three-way talks.

New START limited the number of nuclear weapons that the US and Russia could use to 1,550 each. Washington says that Russia has already gone over this limit, and China is said to be catching up quickly. When the treaty expired on February 5 and wasn't renewed, there were no longer any legally binding limits on these doomsday weapons for the first time in decades. Yeaw stressed that the US is not giving up on arms control completely, but is instead working toward a "better agreement" that will lead to fewer nuclear weapons around the world. He also accused Russia of helping China grow, which suggests that Moscow is giving Beijing technology or know-how to help it get stronger.

Things got even worse when Yeaw backed up American claims that China had been secretly testing nuclear weapons. He used information from Kazakhstan to guess that the 2.75-magnitude underground explosion at China's Lop Nur test site on June 22, 2020, was a 10-ton nuclear bomb. Yeaw warned that China might be getting ready for bigger tests, even though the U.S. has been hinting at this for years. In October of last year, President Trump said the same thing again: the U.S. might start testing again to keep up with what he called China's "covert explosions." Shen called it "groundless" and said that the US was using the accusations as an excuse to start its own program again.

The Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) just put out a paper that casts doubt on the explosion claims because they didn't find any unusual satellite activity around Lop Nur during that time. But the US isn't backing down, and there is work going on behind the scenes. According to a source in the State Department, there was a "preparatory" meeting with Chinese officials in Washington right after New START ended. A more in-depth meeting is set to take place in Geneva.

This back-and-forth shows how uncomfortable things are getting in world politics. There are real worries about an uncontrolled arms race now that New START is gone, especially since the US, Russia, and China are still at odds with each other. Because of Russia's war in Ukraine, things are already tense. Now, the threat of nuclear war makes things worse. Beijing says that its arsenal is only for defense and that it has a "no first use" policy. However, the U.S. sees China's buildup—some estimates say it could reach 1,000 warheads by 2030—as a direct threat.

Experts from ICAN and other groups say that we are on dangerous ground without agreements. Since the height of the Cold War, we haven't had any major nuclear restrictions, and no one wants that to happen again. Yeaw's comments about Russia "boosting" China's arsenal also suggest that things are changing, as China and Russia have become closer because of Western sanctions and may be working together on military technology.

For now, talks are only tentative. There may have been some communication between the U.S. and China, but trust is low because there are so many accusations. Beijing won't budge because the U.S. and Russia have so many weapons, as shown by Shen's refusal to talk with the U.S. and Russia. People all over the world are worried about the Conference on Disarmament, which is still going on without making any progress. They hope that more reasonable people will step in before things get worse.

Trump's larger foreign policy is to renegotiate deals that he thinks aren't good enough, so the U.S. wants a "better agreement." But adding China, which has always had a smaller arsenal, might make things harder. Analysts say that Beijing's growth is part of a vicious cycle of one-upmanship that is caused by the U.S.'s work on hypersonics and missile defense.

geo-politics.metaTitle: Trump Threatens Russia Sanctions Unless War Ends
geo-politics.metaDescription: Trump warns Putin of new taxes, tariffs, sanctions on Russia unless Ukraine war ends; US targets energy sector with Biden-era measures costing billions, hitting oil/gas revenues hard.
geo-politics.title: Trump Warns Putin of Economic Measures Unless Russia Ends War in Ukraine
geo-politics.excerpt: President Trump threatens increased sanctions, tariffs on Russia if Putin refuses to negotiate Ukraine peace; focus on vulnerable oil/gas sector amid tightened US restrictions.
geo-politics.imageAlt: Oil pump model with “Sanctions” text and U.S. flag background symbolizing energy sanctions on Russia

content.text: The current date is February 25, 2026. President Donald Trump has warned Russia that he will impose economic measures including taxes, tariffs, and sanctions unless Russian President Vladimir Putin agrees to end the war in Ukraine. While it is far from clear whether economic pressure alone can bring Putin to the negotiating table, Russia’s oil and gas industry looks to be the most vulnerable sector of his wartime economy.

United States sanctions on Russia’s energy industry have already been tightened in the first weeks of 2025. Just before leaving the White House, outgoing US President Joe Biden fired a parting salvo of comprehensive new sanctions on Russian oil producers, intermediaries, tankers, traders, and ports handling both oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG). This package was widely seen as one of the most aggressive since the start of Russia’s full-scale invasion. The impact is already being felt globally. Some banks in India, which currently takes around 40 percent of all Russian oil supplied to international markets, are reportedly blocking payments for Russian oil imports. Meanwhile, fleet capacity to service Russian crude exports is expected to shrink significantly due to the latest restrictions.

With oil sanctions also targeting major producers such as Surgutneftegaz and Gazprom Neft as well as more than 180 vessels in the Russian oil fleet, some observers are now predicting that the Kremlin could lose up to $24 billion during the coming year. This would be equal to around one percent of the country’s projected GDP. These latest sanctions come as Moscow is already adjusting to the end of gas transit through Ukraine, after Kyiv refused to extend a five-year deal that expired at the start of the current year. With the termination of this gas transit agreement, Russia has lost another sizable chunk of the European market.

Trump vowed during his January 20 inaugural address to “drill, baby, drill.” Since then, initial steps in support of the United States fossil fuels sector have included lifting the Biden administration’s freeze on export permits for LNG projects. Many now expect to see more LNG being exported from the United States to Europe, potentially replacing remaining Russian gas deliveries. Increasing US exports at a time when the Russian gas industry is already facing growing obstacles would place Trump in a strong position ahead of negotiations over a possible settlement of the war in Ukraine.

Trump could potentially increase the pressure on Putin by urging the Ukrainian authorities to ban the transit of Russian crude via Ukraine to Hungary. There is currently a bill in the Ukrainian parliament calling on the government to stop oil transit and deprive the Kremlin of up to $6 billion in sales to European buyers. Additional options include a lower price cap, further sanctions on remaining shipments, and expanded secondary sanctions.

The United States may have fewer options in terms of gas-related sanctions. With demand from key LNG importers such as China and India projected to recover in 2025, US exports may be diverted to Asia, leaving Europe more reliant on Russian LNG and pipeline gas. Additional LNG production from Canada’s western coast could create greater supply options later this year, but that may not be enough to satisfy European consumers or address concerns over rising energy bills.

While Trump’s efforts to undermine Russia economically will face a range of practical challenges, there is no question that Putin’s energy empire is looking increasingly fragile. Russia’s Gazprom in particular appears to be in a difficult position. The Kremlin’s flagship energy company has reported multi-billion dollar losses in the past two years, with this trend likely to worsen in 2025 due to the end of Ukrainian gas transit. The outlook for Gazprom is currently so troubled that the company is reportedly seeking to increase domestic gas prices.

The new United States administration has been quick to signal that it sees the Russian economy as the Putin regime’s most vulnerable point. Trump clearly aims to exploit this weakness in order to end the war in Ukraine. US efforts are likely to focus on the energy industry, which serves as the engine of the Russian war machine.

Ideally, the United States will work closely with the EU and UK in the coming months to expand current sanctions on the Russian energy sector while also working to tighten up the implementation of existing measures. This would send an unambiguous message to Moscow that Russia’s current economic woes will only worsen if Putin rejects a negotiated settlement and refuses to end the invasion of Ukraine.

This economic attack is dangerous in the end, but it is based on the fact that Russia's war machine has been able to work because of money from energy sources. If Trump keeps putting pressure on other countries and working with them, he might be able to tip the scales in favor of talks. The outcome is far from certain because of how the world's markets are doing right now, but Putin has shown in the past that he can bounce back from tough situations. As the fight for energy heats up, the world watches to see what will happen to Ukraine.

geo-politics.metaTitle: US Orders Diplomats to Fight Data Sovereignty Rules
geo-politics.metaDescription: Trump admin cable directs diplomats to counter foreign data localization laws threatening US tech firms; Rubio signs directive opposing GDPR-style rules and promoting free data flows.
geo-politics.title: Exclusive:Trump Administration Orders US Diplomats to Oppose Foreign Data Sovereignty Initiatives
geo-politics.excerpt: Internal State Department cable instructs diplomats to push back against data localization and sovereignty laws that could limit AI, cloud services, and US tech dominance globally.
geo-politics.imageAlt: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at a press conference with American flag backdrop

content.text: The current date is February 25, 2026. The Trump administration has quietly instructed U.S. diplomats around the world to push back hard against foreign governments trying to tighten rules on how American tech giants handle personal data from their citizens. An internal State Department cable dated February 18, obtained by Reuters and signed off by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, lays out the new marching orders in blunt terms: these so-called “data sovereignty” or “data localization” efforts are a direct threat to U.S. interests, especially when it comes to artificial intelligence and cloud computing.

The cable warns that laws forcing companies like Google, Meta, Microsoft, or OpenAI to store or process foreign users’ data locally would “disrupt global data flows, increase costs and cybersecurity risks, limit Artificial Intelligence (AI) and cloud services, and expand government control in ways that can undermine civil liberties and enable censorship.” Diplomats are told to actively “counter unnecessarily burdensome regulations, such as data localization mandates,” and to promote instead Washington’s preferred model of free-flowing data with lighter-touch privacy protections.

This marks a clear shift back to a more confrontational stance after several years of relative quiet on the issue. Under the previous administration there had been more effort to reassure European partners and find common ground on privacy standards. Now the message is unmistakable: any rule that makes life harder for Silicon Valley’s biggest players will face U.S. diplomatic resistance.

Data sovereignty measures have been gaining ground for years, but they’ve accelerated lately. Europe remains the epicenter. The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), already a decade old, forced companies to rethink how they move European citizens’ data overseas and triggered billions in fines for American firms. More recently, several member states have floated or passed stricter localization rules, especially for sensitive sectors like health, finance, and government records. Officials in Brussels and national capitals argue these steps are essential to protect privacy, prevent mass surveillance by foreign governments, and keep strategic data inside the bloc.

The dominance of U.S. AI companies has sharpened those worries. Large language models and other advanced systems rely on enormous datasets, much of it personal information scraped from users worldwide. European regulators and privacy advocates fear that concentration of power in American hands creates unacceptable risks—both for individual rights and for Europe’s strategic autonomy.

Dutch cloud computing expert Bert Hubert, who once sat on the oversight board for the Netherlands’ intelligence services, put it plainly: “Where the previous administration attempted to woo European customers, the current one is demanding that Europeans disregard their own data privacy regulations that could hinder American business.” He sees the cable as evidence that Washington has decided persuasion isn’t working and is shifting to pressure tactics.

The State Department document doesn’t mince words about other players either. It singles out China for “bundling enticing technology infrastructure projects with restrictive data policies that expand its global influence and access to international data for surveillance and strategic leverage.” Beijing has indeed tightened its own data rules in recent years, requiring companies to store Chinese citizens’ information domestically and subjecting cross-border transfers to strict government approval. U.S. officials view these moves as part of a broader effort to control global data flows and give Chinese intelligence services an edge.

The Chinese Embassy in Washington said it was not familiar with the cable but reiterated that “Beijing has always attached great importance to cybersecurity and data security.” The European Commission’s office in Washington did not respond to questions.

The cable also tasks diplomats with monitoring emerging proposals that restrict cross-border data flows and provides ready-made talking points. A key recommendation is to steer partners toward the Global Cross-Border Privacy Rules Forum—a U.S.-led initiative launched in 2022 with Mexico, Canada, Australia, Japan, and a handful of others. The group promotes interoperability between privacy frameworks while keeping data moving freely. Neither the Forum nor its member governments immediately commented.

This isn’t the first time the administration has gone on the offensive against foreign digital regulation. Last year Rubio directed embassies to lobby against the EU’s Digital Services Act, which requires large platforms to remove illegal content faster, including hate speech, terrorist propaganda, and child sexual abuse material. More recently, Reuters reported that Washington is preparing to launch an online portal designed to help Europeans circumvent what U.S. officials describe as overbroad content moderation and censorship rules.

Taken together, these actions signal a broader strategy: treat data policy as a core national security and economic issue, and use diplomatic muscle to keep the global internet as open and U.S.-friendly as possible. Critics say the approach risks alienating key allies at a time when cooperation on AI governance, cyber threats, and supply-chain security is more important than ever. Supporters argue that without pushback, a patchwork of restrictive national rules could fragment the internet, raise costs for everyone, and hand strategic advantages to authoritarian regimes.

For now, the cable makes clear that U.S. diplomats have their orders: defend the free flow of data, challenge localization mandates, and sell the American model wherever possible. Whether that aggressive posture wins friends or creates new enemies in Brussels, Berlin, and beyond will become clearer in the months ahead.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: GitLab Urgent Patches Fix 10 Critical Vulnerabilities in 2025
cybersecurity.metaDescription: GitLab released emergency updates on Dec 10, 2025 fixing 10 serious flaws including high-severity XSS and unauthenticated DoS in CE/EE. Self-managed users must update to 18.6.2 now to avoid risks.
cybersecurity.title: GitLab Issues Critical Security Patches for XSS and DoS Flaws
cybersecurity.excerpt: GitLab's December 10, 2025 emergency patches fix 10 serious security holes including high-severity XSS and DoS vulnerabilities. Self-managed admins must update immediately to versions 18.6.2, 18.5.4, or 18.4.6.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: GitLab logo and CI/CD pipeline dashboard on screen, representing GitLab DevOps platform and critical security patch updates for vulnerabilities

content.text: If you run your own GitLab server, stop what you're doing and check your version. The company's emergency patches, which came out on December 10, 2025, fixed ten serious security holes that affected both the free Community Edition and the paid Enterprise Edition. 18.6.2, 18.5.4, and 18.4.6 are not just "nice to have" updates. GitLab calls them "essential," and security experts are telling all self-managed administrators to use them right away.

These aren't small bugs that hide in corners. They could let hackers run harmful code in your browser, make your whole instance crash, or even get around two-factor authentication. Four of them got ratings of high severity. The other problems are of medium severity and still allow for information breaches, denial-of-service attacks, and sneaky content changes. In short, if your instance is open to the internet, which is true for most of them, you are at risk until you patch.
The Four Big Problems You Can't Ignore
Let's break down the worst ones to help you understand why this is important:

CVE-2025-12716: Cross-site scripting in a wiki (CVSS 8.7). An attacker could add JavaScript to a wiki page by editing it or tricking someone into visiting it. This JavaScript could steal session cookies, take over accounts, or secretly do things as a signed-in user. Wikis are often where teams keep their "living documentation," so they are a great target.

CVE-2025-8405 (CVSS 8.7): HTML injection and bad encoding in vulnerability reports. Think of it as the ability of attackers to put harmful HTML into reports that your security staff look at. The same thing happened as with the wiki XSS: either stealing data or taking over an account.

CVE-2025-12029: There is an XSS flaw in the Swagger user interface (CVSS 8.0). Many developers use Swagger to test APIs, but this problem makes the interface unsafe. With just one click, a fake link could run code that the attacker controls in your browser.

CVE-2025-12562 (CVSS 7.5) is a GraphQL denial-of-service vulnerability that doesn't need authentication to work. This one is really bad. Anyone on the internet can send specially made GraphQL queries, which will use CPU and memory until your GitLab instance stops working. You don't need to log in. That kind of thing could take down an entire development team in an emergency.

WebAuthn, which is a modern passwordless two-factor authentication method that uses hardware keys or biometrics, is also vulnerable to an authentication bypass called CVE-2025-11984 (CVSS 6.8). It has a medium rating, but it could work with other weaknesses to give attackers a real chance in the real world.

The other six problems are ExifTool image metadata crashes, malformed commit API requests that use up resources, more GraphQL DoS vectors, error-message information leaks, HTML injection in merge request titles, and other encoding and validation issues. They all show an attack surface that was bigger than most administrators thought, but none of them are show-stoppers on their own.
Who Should Do Something and Who Is Safe? If you use GitLab.com (the hosted SaaS version), you automatically got the patches. You don't need to do anything.
Updates managed by GitLab also keep loyal customers safe.

But are all instances managed by themselves? You are in charge. If you are still using 18.4.5 or earlier, any 18.5 release before 18.5.4, or any 18.6 release before 18.6.2, you are at risk today. Before patching, older branches that aren't supported anymore should be updated to a release that is still being maintained.

Single-node setups will have downtime because the upgrade process includes moving databases. Even though multi-node or zero-downtime setups can usually roll out the fix without bothering developers, you should still plan ahead.
How to Update (Simple Access)
To install omnibus packages, which are most common on Ubuntu, Debian, CentOS, and other Linux distributions, run your usual apt or yum update and then restart your computer.
Docker: Make new containers and get the new image tags.
Helm/Kubernetes: Update the helm and increase the chart version.
Source installs: Follow the official, well-documented steps for upgrading the software.
GitLab released clear upgrade matrices. To avoid missing anything, be sure to follow the exact path for your current version.
Why This Release Feels Different

GitLab instances are not like most web apps. They hold the most important parts of your business, like deployment keys, API tokens, CI/CD pipelines, source code, and often production secrets. If an exploit works, it could lead to poisoned builds, stolen intellectual property, or a supply-chain disaster that affects all of your software's users.

Maria Chen, a security researcher, said it simply: "These XSS vulnerabilities let attackers pretend to be real users." Script-kiddies can start the unauthenticated GraphQL DoS with just one curl command. Together, they are a big threat to any company that sees GitLab as "just internal tools."

Cybersecurity expert David Rodriguez warned about the WebAuthn bypass, saying, "Even though it's not easy to exploit, it takes away one of the strongest defenses that many teams depend on." In a multi-layered attack, it makes the difference between "they got in" and "they never had a chance."
Things You Can Do If You Can't Patch Today
I know that not every business can shut down and restart their GitLab instance at two in the morning. While you plan the maintenance window, do the following now:
On GraphQL endpoints, set stricter rate limits (GitLab lets you do this in the settings).
Put a Web Application Firewall (WAF) with rules for XSS and GraphQL abuse in front of your instance.
Check the logs for any strange IP addresses that are accessing the Swagger UI, any strange changes to the wiki, or any GraphQL queries that are getting harder to understand.
Check who can access your instance from the outside. If it doesn't need to be public, use a VPN or zero-trust controls.
Make sure your backups are current and have been tested. You need a rollback plan because migrations can go in unexpected ways.
The Big Picture for DevOps Teams

This December 2025 patch cycle is a strong reminder that we need to pay as much attention to the security of the tools we use to make software as we do to the security of the systems that run it. Self-managed deployments are always a little behind GitLab's constantly improving security posture because someone has to click "update."

If your team still sees GitLab updates as optional, it's time to change how you think about them. Set up regular times for maintenance, automate as much as you can, and treat every security alert like it is an emergency.
The GitLab security website has the full official advisory, a list of the exact versions that are affected, and patch notes. Read the updates and send the link to your coworkers to get them going.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: China-Linked Brickstorm Malware Targets VMware in Govt Networks
cybersecurity.metaDescription: US & Canada warn of Brickstorm backdoor by PRC actors targeting VMware vSphere for long-term access in govt & IT systems since 2024. Patch now & hunt IOCs per CISA advisory.
cybersecurity.title: China-Linked Hackers Used 'Brickstorm' Malware to Breach Government Systems
cybersecurity.excerpt: CISA, NSA, and Canadian Cyber Centre alert on Brickstorm malware enabling PRC state-sponsored actors persistent access in VMware vSphere and Windows environments for espionage.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: Hacker in dark hoodie typing on laptop with green code screen, representing state-sponsored cyber espionage, Brickstorm malware, and government network breaches

content.text: The current date is February 25, 2026.

The United States and Canada have jointly warned that hackers linked to China are using a sophisticated piece of malware called Brickstorm to steal login credentials and keep long-term access inside government agencies and major IT networks. This alert came from the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, the National Security Agency, and the Canadian Centre for Cyber Security, who released a detailed advisory together. Brickstorm is a custom-built backdoor that lets attackers slip past defenses, grab sensitive information like passwords and configuration files, and stay hidden inside networks for months at a time. In one confirmed case, the intruders got into a company’s systems back in April 2024 and remained active until September 3, 2025, even though the organization had standard cybersecurity protections in place.

Security teams recovered multiple samples of Brickstorm from different victims and found that the malware is especially good at targeting VMware vSphere environments. VMware vSphere is one of the most widely used virtualization platforms for managing virtual machines and cloud infrastructure in government, corporate, and defense settings. Once the hackers reach a vCenter server or ESXi host, they can drop Brickstorm, which is often written in Go to make it harder to detect on appliances that don’t run full endpoint protection. The malware changes its own code signature to dodge antivirus scans, uses encrypted channels to talk to its command servers, abuses normal system tools so it doesn’t look suspicious, dumps credentials, and moves sideways across the network. It can even copy itself into startup locations or tweak VMware startup scripts to stay persistent.

Broadcom, the company that owns VMware, quickly responded to the advisory by telling customers to apply the latest security patches right away, use strong network segmentation, and follow basic operational security practices. Experts say the attackers usually start by compromising something exposed in the DMZ, like a web-facing server, steal credentials from there, and then pivot internally to reach the virtualization management layer. From that point, they can steal virtual machine snapshots to extract more secrets or even create hidden rogue virtual machines that monitoring tools often miss completely.

The Chinese embassy in Washington pushed back hard against the accusations, calling them baseless and politically driven. A spokesperson named Liu Pengyu said the Chinese government does not encourage, support, or allow cyberattacks of any kind. He insisted that China wants a peaceful and open cyberspace, opposes all forms of cyber theft, and pointed out that the US and Canadian agencies had not provided any solid evidence or even contacted Beijing formally about the matter. This kind of denial has become routine whenever Western governments point fingers at China in cyber incidents.

Technical breakdowns show Brickstorm uses several advanced tricks to stay under the radar: polymorphic code that mutates to avoid detection, encrypted communications often over WebSockets, living-off-the-land techniques that rely on built-in system utilities instead of dropping new files, and built-in features for credential theft and moving deeper into networks. The joint advisory includes a full list of indicators of compromise, YARA rules for hunting the malware, file hashes, network signatures, and step-by-step recommendations for organizations to protect themselves.

Defenders are being told to patch VMware vSphere and related products immediately, enforce multi-factor authentication on every admin account, watch closely for strange network traffic or login attempts, run regular security audits, and carry out penetration tests to find weak spots before attackers do. The advisory stresses that once Brickstorm is inside, the threat actors can hold persistent access for very long periods, which makes this campaign particularly dangerous for anything involving critical infrastructure or sensitive data.

This coordinated warning from the US and Canada shows how seriously both countries take the threat and how important it is to share intelligence quickly when facing advanced, state-backed operations. For anyone managing VMware environments or critical networks, the message is clear: treat this as an active and ongoing risk, hunt aggressively using the provided indicators, and assume that quiet, long-term access could already be happening somewhere in your infrastructure. The full technical report is publicly available on CISA’s website, and organizations are encouraged to review it and act without delay.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: IDEsaster: 30+ Flaws in AI IDEs Risk RCE & Data Theft
cybersecurity.metaDescription: Security researcher uncovers 30+ vulnerabilities in AI-powered IDEs like Cursor, Copilot, Windsurf exposing devs to prompt injection, auto-execution attacks, and full RCE. Urgent fixes needed.
cybersecurity.title: Researchers Discover 30+ Security Flaws in AI Coding Tools
cybersecurity.excerpt: Ari Marzouk's IDEsaster report reveals over 30 critical vulnerabilities in popular AI IDEs including Cursor, GitHub Copilot, and Windsurf, enabling data theft, code poisoning, and remote code execution.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: Developer working on laptop with code displayed, representing AI coding tools, software development environments, and cybersecurity risks in modern IDEs

content.text: Hey developers, security teams, and anyone who’s been happily letting AI write half their codebase lately — you might want to sit down for this one.

In December 2025, independent security researcher Ari Marzouk (better known online as MaccariTA) dropped a bombshell report that’s still sending ripples through the dev world. He spent six months digging into the most popular AI-powered IDEs and coding assistants and found more than 30 serious vulnerabilities — many of them now carrying official CVE numbers. He calls the whole mess “IDEsaster”, and honestly, the name fits perfectly.

We’re talking tools that millions of us use every single day: Cursor, Windsurf, GitHub Copilot, Zed.dev, Kiro.dev, Roo Code, JetBrains Junie, Cline, Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and a bunch more. Out of the 30+ issues Marzouk uncovered, 24 already have CVE assignments. That’s not a handful of edge cases — that’s a systemic problem across the entire category of AI-assisted development tools.

The scariest part? These aren’t your typical “update your library” bugs. They expose a brand-new attack class that basically turns the AI features you love into weapons that can steal your secrets, poison your code, or even take over your entire development machine.
How “IDEsaster” Actually Works — The Three-Stage Nightmare

Marzouk discovered that every single AI IDE he tested fell for the same universal attack chains. And the craziest revelation, straight from his interview with The Hacker News: “All AI IDEs completely ignored the base IDE in their threat model.”

Think about that for a second. These companies built super-smart AI agents that can read files, edit code, run commands, and talk to the internet — but they assumed the old-school IDE underneath (terminals, file watchers, extension APIs, build scripts, etc.) was still “safe” because it’s been around forever. Big mistake.
Here’s how the attack usually plays out in three simple (and terrifying) stages:

1. Prompt Injection to Hijack the AI An attacker slips malicious instructions into something the AI will definitely read — a code comment, README file, package.json dependency note, a pull request description, or even a config file. Once the AI model processes it, it can be told to do almost anything: “Read my .env file and send it to this URL” or “Install this random npm package” or “Edit this file to add a backdoor.”

2. Auto-Approved Tool Calls Most modern AI IDEs have “agent mode” or auto-execution features turned on by default. The AI can read files, write files, run terminal commands, or call other tools without ever asking “Hey human, is this okay?” Zero-click exploitation becomes reality.

3. Weaponizing Trusted Old-School IDE Features This is where IDEsaster gets evil. The AI is now doing the attacker’s bidding and uses completely normal IDE capabilities that no one ever considered dangerous — triggering build scripts, editing workspace settings, firing up debuggers, or abusing file watchers. Suddenly you’ve gone from “harmless prompt” to full remote code execution (RCE) inside your local environment.

Marzouk showed real examples: one chain lets the AI read a sensitive file, then write a JSON file that points to an attacker-controlled server. The IDE innocently makes a GET request to fetch the schema… and boom — your private keys, API tokens, or source code are gone. Another lets attackers override settings so malicious code runs every time you open the project.
Why This Is a Much Bigger Deal Than Previous AI Prompt Injection Research

Earlier studies mostly stopped at “AI can be tricked into reading a file.” IDEsaster goes way further. It proves that once you give the AI real agency inside a full-featured IDE, the entire development environment becomes part of the attack surface.
We’re not talking about theoretical risks anymore. These flaws could let attackers:
* Steal credentials and intellectual property from thousands of developers at once
* Inject persistent backdoors into production code
* Poison entire supply chains through AI-generated (or AI-modified) dependencies
* Compromise CI/CD pipelines that trust the local workspace

Security leaders I’ve spoken with are calling this a wake-up call for the whole industry. AI coding tools often get way more permissions than a human developer would ever have — full filesystem access, network calls, shell execution. When that trust is abused, the blast radius is enormous.
Who’s Affected and What the Vendors Are Doing

Pretty much everyone using modern AI-assisted coding is in the crosshairs. Cursor, Windsurf, GitHub Copilot, and JetBrains Junie are some of the biggest names with confirmed issues (including specific CVEs like CVE-2025-49150 in Cursor and CVE-2025-58335 in Junie). Even tools from big players like Claude Code and Gemini CLI got hit or received security warnings.

Vendors have been patching quickly since the disclosure — some issues were fixed before public release, others are rolling out now. But Marzouk’s research shows the problem runs deeper than just “apply the latest update.” The entire security model for AI agents inside IDEs needs a rethink.
What You Should Do Right Now (Practical Steps)
If you’re a developer or run a dev team, don’t panic — but don’t ignore this either. Here’s what Marzouk and other experts recommend today:
* Turn off automatic tool execution and agent auto-approval features wherever possible.
* Run AI coding assistants only on trusted, clean projects — never open random GitHub repos with AI agents enabled.
* Sandbox your AI tools (use containers, separate user accounts, or isolated VMs if you’re serious).
* Manually review every AI-suggested edit, especially file writes or dependency changes.
* Monitor outbound network connections from your IDE — anything weird going to random domains should raise red flags.
* Only connect to trusted Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers and keep an eye on them.
* Keep everything updated, but also pressure your vendors for better isolation and permission models.
For organizations: treat AI IDEs like any other high-privilege tool. Do security reviews, enforce least-privilege policies, and consider network-level controls that limit what the IDE can reach.
The Bigger Picture — AI Is Changing the Attack Surface Forever

We all love how fast AI coding tools make us. But speed without security is just technical debt with extra steps. IDEsaster proves that bolting powerful LLMs onto tools that were never designed for autonomous agents creates problems nobody saw coming.

As Marzouk put it in his detailed write-up on maccarita.com, this is a brand-new vulnerability class that requires a brand-new way of thinking about “Secure for AI” — better sandboxing, proper threat modeling that includes the base IDE, strict permission systems, and continuous auditing.

The good news? The research is public, vendors are responding, and the community is paying attention. The bad news? Millions of developers are still running these tools in their default, wide-open configurations.

If you’re using Cursor, Copilot, Windsurf, or any other AI-powered coding assistant right now — go check your settings. Disable the scariest auto-features. Review what your AI agent is allowed to touch. And keep an eye on those CVE lists over the next few weeks.

Because in 2026, the biggest threat to your codebase might not be a phishing email or a supply-chain attack from some shady npm package. It might just be the helpful little AI assistant sitting right there in your editor, quietly waiting for the wrong prompt.
Stay safe out there, keep coding, but maybe keep one eye on the AI while you do it.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: JS#SMUGGLER Delivers NetSupport RAT via Hacked Websites
cybersecurity.metaDescription: Securonix uncovers JS#SMUGGLER campaign using compromised legitimate sites to silently install NetSupport RAT via obfuscated JS, HTA, and PowerShell for full remote access.
cybersecurity.title: JS#SMUGGLER Campaign Uses Compromised Websites to Deploy NetSupport RAT
cybersecurity.excerpt: Securonix exposes JS#SMUGGLER: a stealthy drive-by campaign infecting enterprise systems with NetSupport RAT through compromised websites using multi-stage obfuscated JavaScript and fileless techniques.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: Malware warning displayed on digital security dashboard, representing cyber threats, JS#SMUGGLER campaign, and remote access trojan (RAT) infection risks

content.text: If you recently clicked on what looked like a normal website and nothing strange happened, you may have just avoided trouble or, worse, you may not have. Securonix cybersecurity researchers have found JS#SMUGGLER, a new type of malware that sneaks onto computers through hacked legitimate websites. What is the ultimate goal? installing NetSupport RAT, a powerful remote access program that lets hackers take full control of your computer.

This is not a simple attack by a script-kiddie. It looks like a professional red team made this campaign, not a bunch of random hackers. It's very well thought out and has many layers. The results of the deep dive, which Akshay Gaikwad, Shikha Sangwan, and Aaron Beardslee published in early December 2025, are shocking for anyone in charge of keeping businesses safe.

The scary part is that you don't have to download anything or click on any suspicious links. It all starts with going to the wrong (but seemingly normal) website. The attackers have hidden harmful code in real, trustworthy websites. This includes news sites, small business sites, and any site that hasn't been patched in a while. As soon as the page loads, your browser's invisible JavaScript starts to work.

The campaign starts with a sneaky redirect to an outside domain that shows a JavaScript file called 'phone.js' that has been hidden. This small loader quickly checks your device to see if it's a desktop computer or a mobile phone without wasting any time. Why? The attackers want to deliver the right payload so that they can get the most success and the least noise.

Mobile users see a full-screen iframe that looks normal but is actually a trap. A second-stage script that makes a custom URL on the fly and downloads an HTA file, which is a Windows HTML application that runs with the built-in mshta.exe tool, is sent to desktop visitors. These visitors are the real targets of most enterprise attacks. Attackers love HTA files because most people don't know what they are.

The HTA then silently loads and decrypts a PowerShell stager into memory. The usual way to get around antivirus software without using files is to avoid writing files to the disk if at all possible. The PowerShell script then tries to connect one last time, gets the last payload, and installs NetSupport RAT on the computer.
Once NetSupport is in, the victim's game is over. Attackers get:
Full control of the desktop from afar
The ability to read, write, and move around in any file
Run commands, stop processes that are already running, or start new ones.
Steal information and do it in secret.
Use the computer to attack more people.
You can record keystrokes, take screenshots, and do anything else.
The malware also tries to leave as few traces as possible after it has been installed by removing the PowerShell stager and shutting down cleanly.

'This is not just another drive-by download,' said Shikha Sangwan, a researcher at Securonix. JS#SMUGGLER is a professional-grade malware delivery system that has many layers of obfuscation, device-aware targeting, and cleanup after exploitation. It's clear that the attackers know how to get around normal security measures.

This campaign is different because it is smart and can be broken down into smaller parts. JavaScript uses a number of obfuscation techniques, like rotating arrays and mapping numeric indexes, to make it hard to analyze. The loader only goes off once per visitor because it has built-in tracking. This stops it from repeatedly targeting the same victim and setting off alarms. While doing something very bad, they try to make everything look as normal as possible.

Securonix hasn't yet connected JS#SMUGGLER to any country or major cybercrime group. The wide targeting suggests that it is being used opportunistically against companies in many fields, such as manufacturing, healthcare, and finance. If your users use the internet, which they all do, you might be targeted.

This discovery comes right after CHAMELEON#NET, another advanced campaign from the same research team. In that case, phishing emails that look like national social security portals are used. Victims download A.A JavaScript dropper that is very well hidden and found in a BZ2 archive launches a VB.NET loader that uses reflection and a custom XOR cipher to decrypt and run Formbook, another RAT that steals information.

Aaron Beardslee, who is in charge of threat intelligence at Securonix, made the link: 'JS#SMUGGLER and CHAMELEON#NET both show how advanced modern malware campaigns are becoming.' Attackers use multi-stage delivery chains, advanced obfuscation methods, and real infrastructure to stay hidden and improve their chances of success against business targets.

When these two things are put together, they paint a worrying picture: threat actors are getting better at blending in with normal web and email traffic. They don't need obvious malware droppers anymore. Instead, they are using complex JavaScript and in-memory execution to connect legal Windows tools like PowerShell and mshta.exe to get around security measures.

Security experts need to know that perimeter-based tools that are out of date are not enough. Keep an eye on how JavaScript works on web pages, look out for suspicious PowerShell and mshta.exe activity, only run HTA files when you have to, and turn on deep logging for anything related to scripts.

Because they look so innocent, hacked reputable websites are quickly becoming the most popular way to send things. A solution that can easily get around many standard security layers is one that uses fileless methods, heavy obfuscation, and targeting that knows what devices are being used.

If you are in charge of a company's security, now is the time to update your endpoint detection playbooks, look over your web filtering policies, and have a serious talk about how much you trust regular browsing. The next time someone in your company goes to what looks like a harmless website, JS#SMUGGLER, or something even sneakier, might already be one step ahead.

Securonix's full technical description is a good place to look if you want to know the details of IOCs and how to find them. Be aware, keep your systems up to date, and remember that even 'normal' websites could be hacked in 2026.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: STAC6565 Targets Canada: 80% of Attacks on Canadian Firms
cybersecurity.metaDescription: Sophos report reveals STAC6565 (Gold Blade) campaign hits Canada hard with 80% of intrusions from 2024-2025, blending espionage, data theft, and QWCrypt ransomware attacks.
cybersecurity.title: STAC6565 Targets Canada in 80% of Attacks as Gold Blade Expands Operations With QWCrypt Ransomware
cybersecurity.excerpt: Sophos uncovers STAC6565 (Gold Blade, RedCurl) campaign focusing 80% of attacks on Canadian organizations, evolving from espionage to hybrid data theft and QWCrypt ransomware extortion.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: Ransomware warning displayed on laptop screen with security alert icons, illustrating cyberattack threats and data encryption risks for organizations

content.text: If you are in charge of cybersecurity in Canada, this should keep you up at night.

A recent Sophos study that came out in late 2025 says that Canada is now the main hunting ground for a single threat cluster. This cluster is known internally as STAC6565 and has many names, such as Gold Blade, Earth Kapre, RedCurl, and Red Wolf. A shocking 80% of the about 40 confirmed intrusions that Sophos looked into between February 2024 and August 2025 were aimed at Canadian businesses. That rise isn't random. That is a planned, long-term effort.

For a long time, Gold Blade was best known for its secret business spying, especially in Russia and some European countries. They would steal papers without anyone knowing, get in through phishing emails, and then leave. But things changed at the start of 2024. The team changed their minds and started using both traditional spying methods and aggressive ransomware deployment. The end result is a hybrid monster that locks down systems after stealing anything of value with their own special strain of ransomware, QWCrypt, which is made just for high-value, selective extortion.

This campaign has a very narrow focus; almost 80% of the attacks were on Canadian organizations,' said Morgan Demboski, a Sophos researcher who helped lead the investigation. Some of the victims are service providers, factories, retail chains, logistics and transportation companies, non-governmental organizations, tech companies, and operators of important infrastructure. The other 20% of attacks were on the US, Australia, and the UK, but Canada is clearly in the lead right now.
How the attacks really happen

The gang still loves phishing as the first way to get in, even though they have gotten a lot better at it. Once inside, they set up RedLoader, a program made just for this purpose that calls command-and-control servers, gets user and system information, and runs PowerShell scripts to map out the entire Active Directory infrastructure.

Because of that AD reconnaissance stage, this group is especially dangerous. They encrypt more than just computers. They spend time looking for valuable assets, file shares with sensitive data, important servers, and domain administrators. They don't use QWCrypt until they've mapped the network and taken what they want. The attackers not only encrypt the systems, but they also threaten to release the stolen data. This is a classic case of double extortion, but it is done with great care and patience.

This ransomware isn't a smash-and-grab. It's in the works. Attackers seem to pick targets where the victim is most likely to pay to make the problem go away quietly and where the combination of stolen intellectual property and operational downtime will hurt the most.
Why Canada? And what happens next?

Security experts are still trying to figure out what exactly is causing all the attention on Canada. It could just be simple financial opportunism because Canadian businesses in manufacturing, resources, and key services often own a lot of data and have the money to pay. Or there could be a geopolitical or strategic part. The pattern is clear in any case.

Mark Richardson, a cybersecurity expert who has been following Gold Blade for years, says, 'There has been a big change from pure espionage to ransomware deployment.' They are no longer just stealing data; they are holding entire organizations hostage and threatening to release private information. Skilled actors have found that this double-extortion method works very well for them.

The growth of the group is part of a bigger trend we're seeing in the threat landscape for 2025–2026: traditional espionage teams realizing they can make a lot more money by adding ransomware to their tools. Gold Blade (or STAC6565), depending on which vendor's name you like better, is currently halfway between persistent cybercrime at the nation-state level and profit-driven cybercrime.
What Canadian Businesses Should Do Right Now
If you run a business in Canada that is bigger than a small office, treat this as a real and present danger. Sophos and other experts suggest a simple action plan:

First, stop phishing: Make email safer by scanning links, using advanced sandboxing, and giving users good training. Do phishing simulations often that are based on the kinds of lures that Gold Blade uses.
Everyone must use multi-factor authentication without exception. especially for email, cloud services, VPNs, and accounts for administrators.
Network segmentation makes it harder for attackers to move sideways once they get inside. Keep important systems separate and limit access to Active Directory.
PowerShell and controls for scripting: Think about whitelisting apps, limiting scripts that aren't registered, and turning on full logging.
EDR and behavioral monitoring: Make sure your endpoint detection system can find strange AD enumeration and RedLoader-style activity.
To get ready for ransomware, you should regularly test your offline and unchangeable backups, have a tried-and-true incident response plan, and know exactly who to call if QWCrypt shows up.
Threat hunting: Look for the known signs of the campaign. Sophos has released IOCs. Download them and take steps to protect yourself.

For smaller businesses that can't afford big security teams, the basics are still important: keep everything up to date, use strong, unique passwords with manager assistance, enable multi-factor authentication, and if you don't have 24/7 network monitoring, think about managed detection services.
The More Complete Picture for 2026

What bothers me the most is the pattern, not just this one group. Ransomware, regional focus campaigns, customized toolkits, deep Active Directory penetration, and hybrid motivations are now common tools of the trade for spies. Gold Blade's sudden love for Canada could be a passing phase or the start of something more lasting. It is clear that Canadian businesses are being attacked right now, no matter what.

The Sophos report is a strong reminder. If your business has been thinking of ransomware as 'something that happens to other people' or 'we're too small to matter,' it's time to change your mind. These attackers are skilled, patient, and increasingly going after places like Canada where the payoff is high and defenses are still catching up in far too many cases.

Read the whole Sophos report if you want to know the technical details, IOCs, and how to find them. Then, take it to your next meeting with the leaders. In 2026, it won't be possible to wait for an attack to happen before making security better.
Be careful out there, Canada. The wolves, or more accurately, the Red Wolves, are at the door.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: Fortinet Ivanti SAP Urgent Patches: Auth Bypass & RCE Risks
cybersecurity.metaDescription: Fortinet, Ivanti & SAP release emergency patches for CVSS 9.8+ flaws enabling auth bypass, session hijacking & remote code execution. Apply now to avoid exploitation.
cybersecurity.title: Fortinet, Ivanti, and SAP Release Emergency Security Patches for Critical Vulnerabilities
cybersecurity.excerpt: Fortinet, Ivanti, and SAP issued critical December 2025 patches for high-severity vulnerabilities allowing authentication bypass, session hijacking, and remote code execution.
cybersecurity.imageAlt: Ivanti logo displayed at a cybersecurity industry event, representing enterprise security software and critical vulnerability patch updates for 2025

content.text: If your company uses SAP systems, Ivanti endpoint management, or Fortinet firewalls, stop what you're doing and check the status of your patch. As of late December 2025, three major corporate manufacturers have put out urgent fixes for some very dangerous vulnerabilities. We're talking about flaws that let attackers run code from a distance and authentication bypasses that might let them get around login panels. These aren't strange edge cases; they're the exact weaknesses that ransomware groups and nation-state actors like to exploit. That's why security teams everywhere are rushing.
Let's break it down vendor by vendor so you know exactly what you're dealing with.
Fortinet: Two Nightmares with CVSS 9.8 Authentication Bypass

Fortinet released patches for CVE-2025-59718 and CVE-2025-59719, but they only got a 9.8 out of 10. The problems are caused by SAML messages being handled incorrectly and cryptographic signature checks not working. FortiOS, FortiWeb (a web application firewall), FortiProxy, and FortiSwitchManager are some of the products that are affected.

The worst part? If FortiCloud SSO is turned on (even by accident), an attacker who isn't authenticated can make a fake SAML response and log in as anyone without a password, MFA, or any other security measures. Even though Fortinet says that FortiCloud SSO is turned off by default, many administrators turn it on when they enroll devices with FortiCare support. If this sounds like you, treat it like an emergency.
Disabling FortiCloud SSO right away is a short-term fix until you can patch it.You shouldn't check "Allow administrative login using FortiCloud SSO."
CLI: set admin-forticloud-sso-login deactivate end config system global
Next, install the updates and keep an eye on your authentication logs for any strange activity.
Ivanti Endpoint Manager: Stored XSS Turns Into Admin Session Hijacking

CVE-2025-10573 (CVSS 9.6) was fixed in Endpoint Manager (EPM) 2024 SU4 SR1 after stored XSS became admin session hijacking. There is a stored cross-site scripting flaw in the EPM dashboard. Ryan Emmons, a researcher at Rapid7, found it and explained how bad it is: an attacker connects a fake managed device to your EPM server, puts bad JavaScript into the admin panel, and then waits. The script can take over an administrator's entire session as soon as they visit the hacked page, even if they are just looking at it.

That's right: an administrator with special access can take over their session with just one careless click or page refresh. After that, they can do almost everything that the administrator can do in EPM.

Ivanti also fixed three other serious bugs in the same release: CVE-2025-13662 (a crypto verification bug that lets code run), CVE-2025-13659, and CVE-2025-13661 (both RCE bugs). There haven't been any public exploits yet, but time is running out.
Three Criticals That Could Bring Down SAP's Core Business Systems on Patch Tuesday in December
Three of the 14 security holes that SAP fixed in their December security bundle are especially bad:

CVE-2025-42880 (CVSS 9.9): Code injection into SAP Solution Manager. This one is especially scary because Solution Manager is at the center of most SAP landscapes and is in charge of setting things up, applying patches, and keeping an eye on everything.
CVE-2025-55754 (CVSS 9.6) fixes a number of Apache Tomcat security holes that affect SAP Commerce Cloud.
The SAP jConnect SDK has a deserialization flaw (CVE-2025-42928; CVSS 9.1) that lets remote code run, but only if the user has higher privileges.

After naming two of them, Onapsis researchers Thomas Fritsch and his team didn't hold back: "Solution Manager is a core component." It is very important that remediation be done right away. If attackers get in, they could put the whole SAP ecosystem at risk. Think about how long it would take to recover, how long operations would be down, and how many data breaches there would be.
Why this December patch cycle seems different

It's not a coincidence that three big companies released important fixes at the same time; it shows that the threat landscape is getting worse very quickly. Ransomware groups and advanced persistent threats are looking for these kinds of weaknesses, such as weak authentication controls, cached XSS in administration consoles, problems with deserialization, and failures to verify signatures. SAP runs the business backend, Ivanti manages endpoints, and Fortinet is on the edge. All three vendors have solutions that are very important to networks.

Maria Rodriguez, a cybersecurity expert who has been watching how businesses patch their systems for years, said, "This December patch cycle is one of the most important we've seen in years." Companies that use SAP, Ivanti, or Fortinet should treat these upgrades like emergency updates. The weaknesses being looked at are exactly the kinds of holes that state-sponsored hackers and ransomware groups look for when they attack business networks.
What You Must Do Right Away (No Excuses)
Check the inventory: Find every instance of SAP, Ivanti EPM, and Fortinet in your environment right now. Include on-premises, cloud, and shadow IT.

Patch as soon as you can: Give systems that are connected to the internet 24 to 48 hours, and systems that are only used inside the company no more than 72 hours. If you can, test in staging, but don't wait.
The first thing you can do is turn off FortiCloud SSO right away. Check Ivanti admin sessions for any strange behavior. Make patching for SAP Solution Manager your top priority.
Increase monitoring: Add more logging for running PowerShell scripts, trying to log in, and strange dashboard loads. Watch for signs of abuse.
As part of privilege hygiene, make sure that least-privilege is enforced everywhere, especially for administrators who use these consoles.
To get ready for backups and IR, test restorations and make sure that backups are offline and can't be changed. Keep your contacts close by and your incident response playbook open.
Keep track of everything: Write down the status of patches for compliance audits and insurance purposes.

In today's threat landscape, Dr. Alan Chen said it best when he said, "Patch latency and breach probability are closely related." These security holes in SAP, Ivanti, and Fortinet are easy targets for attackers. Quick patching makes an organization's attack surface much smaller. People who are late are more likely to be targeted by attacks that are planned or take advantage of the situation.

This Patch Tuesday is different from the rest. It serves as a reminder that in late 2025, attackers will be most interested in enterprise platforms. If you're using any of these things, you should think of the upgrades as urgent. The holiday slowdown is not a good reason when a full breach could be the other option.

cybersecurity.metaTitle: US Sanctions Russia UAE in Cyber Tools Theft Case
cybersecurity.metaDescription: US imposes cyber sanctions on Russian/UAE-linked individuals & entities for harmful tools and L3Harris trade-secret theft; ex-executive gets 87 months prison.
cybersecurity.title: US Imposes Cyber-Related Sanctions on Russian and UAE Individuals and Entities Over Harmful Cyber Tools
cybersecurity.excerpt: Treasury and State Dept target four people and three entities for cyber tool distribution threatening US security; linked to $1.3M L3Harris exploit sale to Russian broker.
