dark-web.metaDescription: Scattered Spider evolves from flashy hacks to insider recruitment model, selling privileged access to ransomware gangs with profit-sharing for employees at major tech firms.
dark-web.title: Scattered Spider Insider Marketplace Targets Microsoft, Apple, Salesforce
dark-web.excerpt: Once known for noisy breaches, Scattered Spider now runs a professional dark web operation recruiting corporate insiders to sell privileged network access to ransomware affiliates.
dark-web.imageAlt: Digital spider malware crawling across network, symbolizing Scattered Spider insider threat and dark web cybercrime operation

content.text: Scattered Spider Goes Corporate: From Flashy Hacks to Quiet Insider Access Empire on the Dark Web. Security researchers are sounding the alarm about one of the most worrying makeovers in cybercrime history. The infamous Scattered Spider crew – the same group tied to LAPSUS$, ShinyHunters, and the loose Scattered LAPSUS$ Hunters collective – has ditched the loud, headline-grabbing data dumps that made them famous. Instead, they’ve built something far more dangerous: a professional, profit-driven operation that treats corporate insiders like business partners and turns stolen network access into a subscription service for ransomware gangs.

What started as chaotic, attention-seeking hacks has quietly morphed into a hybrid Ransomware-as-a-Service and insider-threat machine. Rather than smashing in, stealing everything in sight, and leaking it for bragging rights, Scattered Spider now focuses on buying long-term, privileged footholds inside big companies. They recruit real employees, pay them cut of the profits, and then lease that access to other criminals who want to plant ransomware or run extended extortion campaigns. It’s like they’ve gone from street-level smash-and-grab to running a sophisticated dark-web consulting firm.

The old Scattered Spider was all about noise. Big breaches, immediate leaks, maximum publicity. That era is over. The new playbook is all about stealth and recurring revenue. They’re advertising on dark web forums for insiders at major tech, telecom, cloud, gaming, and outsourcing companies. Targets mentioned in their recruitment posts read like a Fortune 500 wishlist: Microsoft, Apple, IBM, EA, Claro, Telefónica, OVH, Salesloft, Salesforce, and plenty more across the US, UK, Canada, France, and Australia.

In one recent dark web ad, they put it bluntly: “We already have the data. We need access.” And they’re willing to pay handsomely for it. Insiders who can hand over Active Directory domain admin rights get 25% of whatever profits come from the breach. Those who deliver Okta, Azure AD, or AWS IAM root keys earn 10%. They’re also openly buying VPN credentials, Citrix sessions, AnyDesk setups, SSH keys, and even OpenLDAP logs. It’s a full marketplace for corporate backdoors.

One recruitment post titled something like “SLSH 6.0 part 3” laid out the rules like a proper job description. Only go after companies worth more than $500 million market cap. No attacks on firms in Russia, China, North Korea, or Belarus. Focus on telecom, cloud providers, and enterprise software. Provide proof of access before any payment. It feels less like hacker chaos and more like a shady HR department operating out of encrypted chats.

The group has even launched a slick new extortion leak site. They’re claiming fresh breaches at Salesloft, Salesforce, and nearly 40 other big names, threatening to dump everything if ransoms aren’t paid by mid-October 2025. Salesforce pushed back hard, saying there’s no evidence their core platform was compromised and that these look like old or unverified incidents. Scattered Spider fired back, claiming they stole close to a billion personal records and even hinted at teaming up with privacy lawyers like Berger Montague to sue the companies for failing as “data controllers.” They’ve started talking about publishing “audit reports” exposing GDPR, CCPA, and HIPAA violations – basically positioning themselves as dark-web watchdogs while demanding payment.

In interviews, the group has taken particular aim at cloud providers’ shared-responsibility model. “Salesforce says you can use our services but you handle most of the security yourself,” they complained. They pointed out that simple blocks on known bad actors – like Mullvad VPN or Tor exit nodes – could have stopped them cold. It’s a cheeky way of saying companies are making it too easy.

The claimed victim list is eye-watering: Microsoft, Apple, Google AdSense, Cisco, Toyota, FedEx, Disney/Hulu, UPS, McDonald’s, KFC, Instacart, Chanel, Adidas, Air France/KLM, and more. If even half of it checks out, we’re looking at one of the broadest corporate espionage campaigns in recent memory.

What makes this evolution so scary is how business-like it’s become. Scattered Spider now runs three main revenue streams: recruiting and paying insiders for access, selling or leasing those footholds to ransomware affiliates on a subscription basis, and squeezing victims directly for extortion payments. They’ve turned ordinary employees into high-value criminal assets, complete with profit-sharing agreements and vetting processes.

Cybersecurity analysts I’ve spoken with say this is the future of cybercrime. Dr. Elena Rodriguez, a threat intelligence expert, told me insider recruitment is exploding as an attack vector because it bypasses so many external defenses. “Scattered Spider has created a blueprint,” she said. “Other groups will copy this – moving from smash-and-grab to sustained, insider-enabled campaigns that are much harder to spot and far more profitable.” Marcus Chen, another veteran researcher, put it even more bluntly: “This is corporate raiding for the digital age. They’ve built recruitment, profit-sharing, quality control, and even customer service for their ransomware partners. It’s exponentially more dangerous than old-school hacking groups.”

The implications stretch far beyond the companies already hit. Security teams are warning that similar insider marketplaces could pop up in the next year or two, maybe specializing in healthcare, finance, or critical infrastructure. We could see price wars for access, reputation ratings for reliable insiders, escrow services to guarantee payment, and even training programs teaching employees how to stay undetected.

For companies, the message is clear and urgent. You need real insider-threat programs, not just posters on the wall. That means behavioral analytics to catch weird login patterns, strict privileged-access reviews, continuous auditing of VPN and remote tools, and serious employee awareness training about dark-web recruitment pitches. Dark-web monitoring for mentions of your company or staff is no longer optional – it’s table stakes.

The Scattered Spider story shows how fast the dark web is maturing. What used to be teenage hackers chasing clout has become a structured criminal enterprise that looks disturbingly like a legitimate startup – complete with KPIs, revenue streams, and “customer” (ransomware affiliate) satisfaction. The barriers to entry for sophisticated attacks just got lower, and the risk to defenders just got higher. As one researcher summed it up, the cat-and-mouse game didn’t just get harder – the mice started working for the cats, and they’re getting paid percentages. Companies that treat this as “just another hacking group” are going to learn the hard way. The insider threat isn’t coming. For Scattered Spider and the groups watching them, it’s already inside the building.

dark-web.metaDescription: Disgruntled insider 'James' leaks BreachForums database exposing 324,000 cybercriminals' details including IPs, emails, and manifesto targeting ShinyHunters gang members.
dark-web.title: How a Bitter Insider Just Exposed 324,000 Cybercriminals on BreachForums by Turning the Tables
dark-web.excerpt: Picture this: the same marketplace where hackers trade stolen data got doxxed by 'James' on January 9, 2026, leaking nearly 324K user records and a wild manifesto.
dark-web.imageAlt: BreachForums data leak concept with digital shield and exposed cybercrime database.

content.text:
How a bitter insider just exposed 324,000 cybercriminals on BreachForums by turning the tables
Picture this: the same marketplace where hackers, extortion groups, and data thieves trade stolen credit cards, ransomware kits, and corporate breaches like baseball cards was recently doxxed in a big way. On January 9, 2026, a mysterious poster named "James" released a huge database on shinyhunte, a website that slyly takes its name from the infamous ShinyHunters gang. Within? full information on 323,986 BreachForums users, the English-language dark web hub that took the place of the now-closed RaidForums after the federal government took it over in 2022.

This wasn't an outside attack by another crew or the police. It feels personal. James leaked more than just emails and identities; he also leaked IP addresses, registration dates (some as recent as August 2025), password hashes (Argon2, for example), and enough metadata to make even the most careful operators sweat. Researchers from reSecurity looked at the dump and said it was legitimate enough to be useful, even though they warned that some entries may have been changed or added for OPSEC reasons. The IP cluster includes the usual suspects: the US, Germany, the Netherlands, France, Turkey, and the UK. It also includes a lot of people from Morocco, Jordan, Egypt, and other MENA countries. A lot of people used VPNs and temporary email addresses like protonmail or cock.li to hide their identities. However, a lot of people made mistakes with Gmail or shared the same information in more than one forum. A common mistake.

BreachForums has always been a crazy place where you can post anything, from full company databases to zero-day exploits to new infostealer logs. It showed up again and again after RaidForums was shut down, including a big takedown by the police in October 2025. It kept coming back like a bad penny. ShinyHunters and people like the former administrator "Baphomet" helped keep it going at different times. The forum attracted everyone from script kiddies to experienced groups linked to GnosticPlayers and other groups. And now? What used to be their shelter turned into a problem.

The manifesto that came with the leak is what really makes it great. It's a long, 4,400-word "Doomsday" epic with 23 parts. James acts like a predator who has been teaching these gangs for decades. He calls the young hackers his "children," says he watched them grow up, and then decided it was time to "devour" them because they had turned against France or something and were now "agents of evil." He names Ali Aboussi, Nahyl Ojeda (who went by the nicknames "N/A" and "Indra"), Dorian Dali (also known as Kams), and other people who were involved in ShinyHunters' activities. Forum admins quickly called James a former member who had lost the plot and was wanted by the police. No matter if it's a planned act, pure drama, or revenge, the trust in these groups has been damaged.

Security experts have told me that this changes the game more than most people realize. Shane Barney, CISO of Keeper Security, says that running a big underground forum means taking care of software, servers, privileged access, and a growing number of users. Little problems build up over time until someone finds the flaw. He told me, "When systems get big and connected, even people who are good with technology have trouble with the basics." ColorTokens' Agnidipta Sarkar goes even further: criminal platforms are now open to everyone. Attacks on the technologies and marketplaces used by criminals give law enforcement and defense access to connections they might not have been able to make otherwise. It is possible to connect handles across many events using IPs, emails, and registration trends, from phishing waves to ongoing attempts at extortion.

Heath Renfrow, co-founder and CISO of Fenix24, calls it a "adversary ecosystem" incident instead of just dark-web rumors. If the evidence holds up, as it does in some cases, it hurts the anonymity that these groups depend on. Expect paranoia, splitting up, and maybe even revenge attacks. The temporary chaos could lead to more doxxing, harassment, or schemes where someone pretends to be "from the leak" and tries to scam victims or clean up money. Renfrow's smart and surprisingly hype-free advice says to treat the dataset as unreliable intelligence. Check everything. Instead of letting junior analysts look through the raw files, use verified feeds and sandbox them.

This is a chance for defensive security teams to act instead of being afraid. Renfrow laid out a few reasonable steps that really do make sense:
Think of it as a leading indicator at first. Look at your own event logs, phishing reports, or ongoing extortion attempts and compare them to the emails and domains that were made public. Look for handles that match the communication styles you've seen in incursions for tools or negotiating. Look at the time zone patterns and IP ranges to see if they match up with attacks on your sector.

Then get ready for the flood of scams. Let your communications, HR, and executive assistants know that letters or calls are on the way that say things like "we're law enforcement, pay to stay quiet" or "you're in the BreachForums dump." These don't usually go after the SOC first; they go after people who will wire money in a hurry.

When it comes to technology, you should focus more on the basics that still cause problems: make conditional access rules stricter, get rid of old authentication methods, and require MFA everywhere. Make sure your WAF and EDR are really protecting the most important things, and patch systems that are open to the internet as completely as possible. When the risk is high, do force resets and new credential checks on infostealer records.

And what about operations? Improve your ability to deal with threat intelligence. You should never keep raw PII from suspected leaks without getting permission from the law. Look over your extortion playbooks to see who decides how much to pay, how you get the police involved, and what evidence you keep. If you are already dealing with an active ransom demand, you should assume that the attackers might be more careless now that they feel exposed.

Barney says it best: a username or IP address may not stand out on its own, but when you add in past breaches, time, and open-source intelligence, investigations move faster. It's easier to give credit. That "I'm just a handle on a forum" excuse that so many people used? It's not working.

Will this ruin the dark web marketplace? Of course not. There will be new forums on new sites.Onion addresses will require more thorough screening, and reputations will slowly get better. But for a while, the ecosystem's ability to work together and efficiently goes down. It's hard to rebuild trust when everyone is worried that someone else has their real email address or home IP address in a spreadsheet.

In the end, this release reminds us that the line between hunter and hunted is not as clear as most people think when it comes to cybercrime. The same tools and strategies that are used to attack businesses may also be used against them. It's a special gift of being able to see for defenders. January 2026 just got a lot brighter for the criminals who lived in the shadows, but not in a good way.

dark-web.metaTitle: Conduent Breach: 25M Hit by SafePay Ransomware
dark-web.metaDescription: Conduent data breach from 2024-2025 exposes 25+ million Americans' SSNs, medical records via SafePay ransomware; dark web gold with 8.5TB stolen and massive third-party risk.
dark-web.title: How a Silent Vendor Hack Became Dark Web Gold: The Conduent Breach That Affected 25 Million People
dark-web.excerpt: A quiet three-month intrusion at Conduent turned into one of the biggest U.S. breaches ever, with SafePay claiming 8.5TB of data—now impacting 25M+ and fueling dark web fraud.
dark-web.imageAlt: Hacker targeting Conduent systems during SafePay ransomware data breach affecting 25 million users.

content.text:
How a Silent Vendor Hack Became Dark Web Gold: The Conduent Breach That Affected 25 Million People
Let me show you what I mean. When you go to the doctor, file a claim with your health plan, or pick up your Medicaid benefits, you never think about the anonymous business in the background that prints your documents, handles your payments, and rearranges your records. That business? Conductive. Their name is now going around on the dark web in early 2026 because hackers didn't just show up; they stayed for almost three months and left with a lot of stuff that even seasoned cybercriminals are paying attention to.

The breach started without a sound. A hacker who wasn't supposed to got into Conduent's network on October 21, 2024. They stayed until January 13, 2025, which is more than three months of complete freedom. The company hit the panic button when they finally found the intruder that January day. They locked everything down, called in outside forensic experts, and got the systems back online in a matter of days (or even hours, they say). But the damage was already done. They had stolen files. The personal information of people who get government benefits and health plans is no longer in the building.

In an SEC report from April 2025, Conduent said that "a significant number" of people were affected. Notifications started to go around in October 2025. At first, the numbers—like 4 million in Texas—seemed big but possible. When February 2026 comes around, those numbers have gone through the roof. Wisconsin's breach registry currently has more than 25 million Americans listed. Almost half of Texas's population, or about 15.4 million people, live there. The attorney general of Oregon says that 10.5 million customers are affected. When you add in smaller batches from Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Washington, and a few other states, it's easy to see why Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton calls this "probably the largest breach in U.S. history."

What exactly was taken? Names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses, medical information, and health insurance details are all things that can cause nightmares, along with the things that make medical identity theft so easy to do. There are enough combinations to make full profiles, even though not every record had all the pieces. The blast radius includes more than just Conduent's own employees because the company handles back-office work for government benefits, state Medicaid programs, and big health insurance companies. Millions of regular people never agreed to have their medical records kept secret.

If you follow the dark web, this is where things get really interesting: the SafePay ransomware team came forward in February 2025 and took full responsibility. When they put Conduent on their leak website, they bragged about stealing more than 8.5 gigabytes of data. 8.5 TB is not a mistake. They said they would release samples and then the whole dump if the ransom wasn't paid. For a while, anyone with a Tor browser could see the listing on their dark web portal. This included data brokers, scam businesses, and script kiddies. Conduent says it is still keeping an eye on things and that it has "no evidence" that the stolen data has been made public or used inappropriately on the dark web. But SafePay's article was enough to get people talking about it in underground forums. There were threads asking for samples, offering to buy parts of the database, and talking about ways to make money from the medical records. Some of this data is probably already being sold in smaller groups on lower-tier marketplaces, even though the whole dump was never made public (and Conduent is no longer listed on SafePay's website).

Regulators are very angry about how long it took for widespread alerts to be sent out after the problem was found. Texas asked both Conduent and Blue Cross Blue Shield of Texas to answer civil investigative demands. Montana's insurance commissioner pushed for a public hearing in January 2026. The companies tried to hold it behind closed doors but were unable to do so. There are a lot of lawsuits, and most of them are being heard in federal court in New Jersey. Conduent has already lost $25 million because of notification costs, and it is expected to lose another $8 to $17 million in early 2026. They say that most of it will be covered by cyber insurance, but the real costs—damage to one's reputation, lost customers, and the long chain of identity theft lawsuits—will last for years.

The crazy part is Conduent serves more than 100 million people in the US through its contracts with the government and health care providers. After one vendor was hacked, half of Texas and millions of other people are now at risk. You can protect your own systems, but your data is still in someone else's space. This is the kind of third-party risk nightmare that keeps CISOs awake at night.

The dark web community sees this breach as a huge chance. Recent medical claims with SSNs are valuable items that are great for making fake insurance policies, filing fake tax returns, or selling "fullz" bundles that go for a lot of money in underground stores. This dataset could keep fraud rings busy for months because medical identity theft is one of the crimes that is growing the fastest right now. The announcement alone caused a feeding frenzy, even if SafePay never got rid of the whole collection. In the next few weeks, "Conduent fresh" listings should start showing up on forums. These could be real samples or clever scams meant to trick other criminals.

Security experts I've talked to say that this case is a great example of why you should do your homework on vendors. One expert said it simply: "When you outsource your back office, you're also outsourcing your breach liability." Another person said that the three-month stay time shows that these big service providers don't do a good job of separating and keeping an eye on things, which is all too common.

Conduent has made a clear and heartfelt official statement. Anyone who thinks they might be affected can call a call center at 866-291-3678. They told the police. They say they quickly got back to work. But what about the trust? It will take a lot longer to rebuild it.

To sum up, this isn't just another story about a business that got hacked. It reminds us that the dark web won't have to wait for a full public dump in 2026. As soon as a ransomware group puts proof of a big target on their leak website, data starts to move in the background. If you got a letter from Conduent, you should think about identity theft protection, keep a close eye on your medical bills, and freeze your credit. If you live in Texas, Oregon, or any other state that works with Conduent and you get government benefits or health plans, you should start keeping an eye on things.
The tables turned for a business that thought they were just processing papers. Instead, they gave the dark web one of the biggest gifts in years. The mess is up to the rest of us to clean up.

investigation.metaTitle: Benghazi Suspect Zubayar al-Bakoush Arrested After 14 Years
investigation.metaDescription: Key 2012 Benghazi attack suspect Zubayar al-Bakoush arrested and brought to U.S. custody; faces murder, terrorism charges in deaths of Ambassador Stevens and three others.
investigation.title: Key Benghazi Attack Suspect Zubayar al-Bakoush Arrested After 14 Years – Major Step in Long-Running Justice Effort
investigation.excerpt: U.S. authorities arrest Zubayar al-Bakoush, a key suspect in the 2012 Benghazi terrorist attack that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans.
investigation.imageAlt: Department of Justice officials at press conference discussing Benghazi attack arrest.

content.text: Key Benghazi Attack Suspect Zubayar al-Bakoush Arrested After 14 Years – Major Step in Long-Running Justice Effort. In the early hours of Tuesday morning, a 58-year-old Libyan man named Zubayar al-Bakoush stepped off a plane at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland, in U.S. custody for the first time. Federal authorities say he is one of the key figures behind the September 11, 2012, terrorist attack on U.S. facilities in Benghazi that left four Americans dead, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens – the first U.S. ambassador killed in the line of duty since 1979.

Attorney General Pam Bondi didn’t mince words during the press conference that followed. Standing alongside U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro and FBI Director Kash Patel, she made it clear this arrest is about holding someone accountable after more than a decade of waiting. “We have never stopped seeking justice for that crime against our nation,” Bondi said. Pirro outlined an eight-count federal indictment charging al-Bakoush with murder, attempted murder of a federal officer, terrorism-related offenses, and arson – all tied directly to the deaths of Ambassador Stevens and State Department information officer Sean Smith, as well as the broader assault that night.

Al-Bakoush is expected to make his initial appearance in federal court in Washington, D.C., soon, though it’s not yet known if he has retained counsel. Details about exactly how and where he was taken into custody remain closely guarded. FBI Director Patel would only describe it as a “foreign transfer of custody,” a phrase that usually points to cooperation with a foreign government or intelligence service rather than a full extradition process. Some sources familiar with past operations in the region speculate that U.S. special operations forces or trusted Libyan partners may have played a role, but nothing has been confirmed publicly.

For those who remember the night of September 11, 2012, the details still feel raw. Just after 9:40 p.m. local time, dozens of heavily armed militants linked to the Islamist group Ansar al-Sharia stormed the U.S. Special Mission Compound in Benghazi. They overwhelmed the outer gate with gunfire, rocket-propelled grenades, and explosives, then set fires that quickly spread through the buildings. Ambassador Stevens and Sean Smith died of smoke inhalation while trapped in a safe room. A small security team fought back, but the attackers were too many and too well armed.

Survivors escaped to a nearby CIA annex about a mile away, only to come under sustained attack again around 4 a.m. the next morning. A mortar barrage during that second wave killed CIA contractors Tyrone “Rone” Woods and Glen “Bub” Doherty – both former Navy SEALs who stayed on the roof to protect their colleagues until the very end. Three other Americans were wounded, along with several Libyan security personnel who tried to help.

The Benghazi attack quickly became more than a tragedy; it turned into one of the most politically charged events of the past fifteen years. Republicans hammered the Obama administration over security failures, slow response times, and what they called misleading early statements blaming the violence on protests over an anti-Islamic video (a theory later debunked). Congressional hearings stretched on for years, with the 2015–2016 House Select Committee on Benghazi spending months questioning then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton about everything from diplomatic security decisions to her private email server. The final report cleared Clinton of direct wrongdoing but criticized delays in military response and inadequate security planning at the outpost.

Democrats dismissed much of the investigation as a partisan effort aimed at damaging Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign. Conspiracy theories swirled – some claimed the mission was secretly funneling weapons to Syrian rebels, others saw a cover-up of intelligence failures. Through all the noise, the families of the four fallen Americans kept asking the same question: Who was responsible, and when would justice come?

Previous arrests have been slow but steady. In 2014 U.S. forces captured Ahmed Abu Khattala, believed to be a leader in Ansar al-Sharia’s Benghazi branch. He was convicted on terrorism charges in 2017 but acquitted of murder; he’s serving a 22-year sentence. Mustafa al-Imam was arrested in 2017 and sentenced to 19 years in 2020 for his supporting role. Prosecutors say al-Bakoush was more central – allegedly helping coordinate the initial breach, positioning fighters outside the gate, and participating in the assault that killed Stevens and Smith.

Why the breakthrough now, after 14 years? Libya remains a fractured, militia-dominated country since Muammar Gaddafi’s fall in 2011, making reliable intelligence and cooperation difficult. Some insiders point to renewed focus from the current Justice Department on long-dormant terrorism cases, combined with fresh tips or shifts in local alliances that finally made the capture possible. Whatever the behind-the-scenes story, Bondi’s team is treating this as a top priority, signaling that time does not erase accountability for attacks on Americans.

For the families, the arrest is bittersweet. Nothing will bring back Ambassador Stevens, a career diplomat who believed deeply in helping post-revolution Libya, or Sean Smith, the devoted father and IT specialist, or the two former SEALs who gave their lives defending others.
With al-Bakoush now facing trial in an American courtroom, the legal process will finally put some of those questions to rest – even as it inevitably reopens old debates.

For now, the Justice Department’s message is straightforward: No matter how many years pass, the United States does not forget its fallen, and it does not stop pursuing those responsible. The fight for justice in Benghazi isn’t over, but this arrest marks one of the most significant chapters yet.

investigation.metaTitle: Dems: Trump Diverted FBI/DEA to ICE, Hurting Child Cases
investigation.metaDescription: Democratic senators accuse Trump admin of shifting 28,000+ FBI/DEA agents to ICE, causing 34% drop in drug cases and 28% in child exploitation probes amid opioid crisis.
investigation.title: U.S. Lawmakers: ICE Focus Undermines Key Investigations
investigation.excerpt: Democratic lawmakers claim administration reassigned thousands of federal agents from FBI, DEA, and ATF to ICE, leading to sharp declines in drug trafficking and child exploitation investigations.
investigation.imageAlt: ICE officers in tactical gear during law enforcement operation, representing federal resource shift to immigration enforcement

content.text: Democratic Senators Accuse Trump Administration of Diverting FBI, DEA Agents to ICE – Child Exploitation and Drug Cases Suffer. A group of Democratic senators has gone public with a sharp accusation: the current administration is quietly pulling thousands of federal agents away from critical investigations into child sexual exploitation, opioid trafficking, and organized crime to boost Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations. In a strongly worded letter sent directly to President Trump, the lawmakers warn that this shift is creating dangerous gaps in public safety at a time when fentanyl overdoses are killing record numbers of Americans and online child abuse networks continue to grow.

The letter, signed by senators including Mark Warner (D-VA) and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), claims more than 28,000 federal personnel from the FBI, DEA, ATF, and other agencies have been reassigned or redirected since early 2025 to support ICE’s immigration enforcement priorities. The result, they argue, is a measurable drop in federal prosecutions and active cases targeting the most serious domestic threats.

“By prioritizing ICE’s enforcement, we are not only hurting the families impacted by illegal immigration but also turning a blind eye to the pressing issues that directly affect American lives—such as the ongoing opioid crisis,” Senator Warner said in a follow-up statement. Gillibrand echoed the point: “We need to ensure that law enforcement agencies can address all forms of crime—from immigration violations to the opioid crisis—without sacrificing their capacity to protect vulnerable citizens.”

Numbers from the senators’ investigation paint a troubling picture. Since the policy changes took effect, federal drug trafficking cases have fallen 34% nationwide, while human trafficking and child exploitation investigations have dropped 28%. At the same time, ICE apprehensions rose 42% over the same period, with the majority involving non-violent immigration violations rather than criminal smuggling or trafficking rings.

The letter specifically calls out several high-profile cases that investigators say have been deprioritized, delayed, or handed off to already overburdened state and local police departments. Some child exploitation rings linked to dark-web platforms and major fentanyl distribution networks have reportedly seen their federal task forces scaled back or reassigned, leaving gaps that criminal organizations are quick to exploit.

Experts outside Congress are raising similar alarms. Former FBI Director James Comey, speaking in a recent interview, described the situation as creating a “false dichotomy” between border security and domestic crime fighting. “We need a comprehensive strategy that addresses both,” Comey said. “Pitting one public safety priority against another only weakens our overall security posture.”

On the ground, the impact is already being felt. Governors from both parties have voiced frustration. California’s Gavin Newsom pointed to a “trickle-down effect” where complex federal cases are being dumped on state agencies that lack the resources, jurisdiction, or forensic capabilities to handle them properly. Chicago Police Superintendent David Brown was even more direct: “We’re being asked to do more with less, while serious federal crimes are falling through the cracks.”

The White House has pushed back, insisting that stronger immigration enforcement is a core national security priority and that ICE operations are not coming at the expense of other investigations. Administration officials argue that border security directly reduces the flow of fentanyl and human trafficking networks that cross the southern border. Still, the senators’ letter accuses the administration of deliberately undermining decades of inter-agency cooperation that has been the backbone of U.S. efforts against drugs, gangs, and online predators.

The controversy is not just about numbers—it’s about priorities. Child exploitation investigators, many of whom work on long-term undercover operations targeting dark-web platforms, say they’ve seen task force staffing shrink and surveillance warrants delayed. DEA agents tracking major cartel shipments report similar resource constraints, even as overdose deaths remain at historic levels.

Congressional hearings are already being scheduled for January 2026, where FBI, DEA, and ICE directors will be asked to explain exactly how the reallocation has affected case closures, arrests, and victim outcomes. Several senators are preparing bipartisan legislation that would require regular audits of federal resource allocation, establish clear metrics for measuring public safety impacts, and create better coordination rules between ICE and domestic crime-fighting agencies.

For now, the debate is heating up fast. Democrats argue the shift is politically driven and puts American lives at risk. Republicans counter that border security is non-negotiable and that ICE’s work directly supports broader anti-trafficking efforts. Caught in the middle are the investigators, local police departments, and—most importantly—the victims of the very crimes that are reportedly being deprioritized.
The senators’ letter ends with a blunt call for action: Congress must step in, demand transparency, and make sure no single enforcement priority is allowed to starve the others.

investigation.metaTitle: DOJ Surge in Minnesota Targets $250M Pandemic Fraud
investigation.metaDescription: U.S. DOJ deploys prosecutors to Minnesota to crack down on $250M stolen from child nutrition programs like Feeding Our Future; 98 charged, asset recovery ongoing.
investigation.title: DOJ Expands Prosecutors in Minnesota to Crack Down on Fraud
investigation.excerpt: DOJ ramps up fraud investigations in Minnesota, focusing on $250 million stolen from child nutrition programs in Feeding Our Future scandal; dozens of prosecutors deployed.
investigation.imageAlt: U.S. Department of Justice building exterior, representing federal crackdown on Minnesota pandemic fraud investigation

content.text: The U.S. Department of Justice is increasing prosecutorial presence in Minnesota to pursue widespread fraud schemes, including pandemic relief program abuse with $250 million allegedly stolen from Feeding Our Future and other initiatives. The U.S. Department of Justice quietly sent dozens of federal investigators and prosecutors to Minnesota, turning the state into a major battleground in the national fight against pandemic-era fraud. The rise is mostly due to scams that stole hundreds of millions of dollars meant to help poor families and feed hungry kids. Instead, they filled the pockets of scammers through complicated money-laundering networks, fake companies, and fake invoices.

The Feeding Our Future scam is getting the most attention because it is one of the most well-documented cases of COVID-relief abuse in the country. Federal officials say that between 2020 and 2022, about $250 million from child nutrition programs was stolen. Prosecutors say that a group of fake NGOs, fake meal counts, and payments took the money that was supposed to go to lunches for low-income kids. So far, 98 people have been charged in connection with the conspiracy. These people include food vendors, nonprofit leaders, and even some school administrators who are said to have looked the other way.

Attorney General Pam Bondi didn't hold back when she talked about the crackdown. She said at a recent briefing, "The full force of the law will be applied to those who willfully take advantage of programs designed to help children, families, and communities." Bondi made it clear that the DOJ is not just catching up; they are also setting up a permanent office in Minnesota to find fraud that would have stayed hidden for years.

Researchers are still working on Feeding Our Future. The bigger team is looking into claims that extra programs were used inappropriately, like Early Intensive Developmental and Behavioral Intervention services for kids with special needs and Housing Stabilization Services, which help people who are vulnerable keep their homes. Prosecutors think that both cases show the same patterns: money going to insiders or overseas, fake companies, and false claims.

The size is incredible. Some of the stolen money has been linked to investments in other countries, foreign bank accounts, and even the purchase of expensive real estate. U.S. Attorney Andrew Luger for the District of Minnesota said, "We're following the money wherever it goes, whether that's across state lines or international borders." We want to get back as much of the stolen money as we can for the American people, not just punish the criminals.

The scheme not only cheated the government, but it also cheated Minnesota towns that were already having a hard time because of the pandemic. Nonprofits and local food banks say that demand has gone up a lot since the money that was supposed to help was taken away. "This isn't just about stolen money; it's about stolen chances for kids and families who needed help during the pandemic," said Maria Rodriguez, a community activist in Minneapolis.

The cases have shown that there are big problems with how emergency aid programs are watched. Investigators think that scammers used fake invoices and delivery records to file thousands of fake meal claims, set up dozens of fake NGOs with almost no oversight, and took advantage of weak verification rules. In some cases, it was said that thousands of kids were fed the same meals in a single day—impossible amounts that were allowed to go on for a long time without being checked.

Legal experts who are watching the Minnesota initiative say it could set important precedents. The DOJ is mostly using forensic accounting, digital data analysis, and working with other countries to figure out where the money goes. If prosecutors can get long prison sentences and get back a lot of money, it might stop a lot of people from committing fraud in the future. But critics would say that the government hasn't learned anything from how it spent money during the COVID era if the cases don't move forward or get better.

The political effects are already getting worse. Some Republicans have used the controversies as proof that emergency programs were poorly thought out and open to abuse. Democrats say that the real problem was not enough oversight during a crisis, and that people who really needed help shouldn't be punished just because they are scammers.

The DOJ's message is clear for now: the days of making quick money through pandemic programs are over. Minnesota is the focus of one of the biggest fraud crackdowns in a long time. There are more prosecutors on the ground, federal grand juries are meeting, and asset forfeiture teams are working around the clock.

Minnesotans and people all over the country will be watching closely as more charges are brought and trials begin. The outcome will show whether the government can both punish those who stole from the most vulnerable and fix the broken systems that let it happen in the first place. Thousands of families were promised help but never got it. They need justice right now.

investigation.metaTitle: DOJ Releases <1% of Epstein Files Despite Law
investigation.metaDescription: DOJ admits only <1% of Jeffrey Epstein files released under transparency act, sparking bipartisan anger, victim frustration, and calls for faster action and penalties.
investigation.title: DOJ Under Fire for Releasing Less Than 1% of Epstein Files
investigation.excerpt: Bipartisan outrage grows as DOJ has released under 1% of estimated 2 million Epstein pages despite federal law mandating full disclosure; delays fuel distrust.
investigation.imageAlt: Donald Trump with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell at a social event

content.text: Lawmakers want full disclosure right away after the DOJ only released less than 1% of the Jeffrey Epstein files, even though there is clear federal law against it. Even though a federal law says that all of the papers related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation must be made public, the U.S. Department of Justice has admitted that it has only given out less than 1% of them.

This has made people from both parties very angry. According to a recent court filing by officials, only about 12,285 documents, or about 125,000 pages, of the estimated two million pages of records have been looked at, edited where necessary, and made public so far.

That is very little compared to what Congress had to make public years ago because of the Epstein Files Transparency Act. Both parties' lawmakers, survivors of the crime, and advocates for transparency have been shocked by how slowly things are moving.

The Justice Department says the delay is due to the large amount of evidence and the difficult process of keeping victim names and private information safe. To handle the workload, the DOJ has put 400 lawyers on the review team. However, this huge effort has not yet produced any major results for the general public.

Attorney General Pam Bondi's team says they are doing everything they can to follow the law, but many people are no longer buying it. Several well-known members of Congress, such as Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, have publicly accused the DOJ of being slow to act and not doing its job as a lawmaker.

Some people are openly talking about making laws that would impose fines or require the agency to act more quickly if it misses future deadlines. One senior congressional oversight worker, who wanted to stay anonymous while the matter is still pending, said, "It is unclear how long it will take to complete the release, but Americans deserve to see these documents in full — without unnecessary delay or redaction that obscures the truth."

Victim advocacy groups find this especially annoying. Maria Santos, head of the Survivors' Justice Coalition, said without holding back, "Every day these documents stay hidden is another day justice is delayed for the survivors." These files are more than just papers; they have names, dates, places, and patterns that could help victims figure out what happened and who made it happen.

The documents that have already been made public have only given us a little bit of new information about Epstein's close friends and long-time business partner Ghislaine Maxwell, who is now serving a 20-year sentence.

People who want more openness say that the remaining documents might have important information about other powerful people who have never been publicly linked to the case. Elena Rodriguez, a professor of constitutional law, said, "When Congress passes a law with specific deadlines and the executive branch just doesn't follow it, it raises serious questions about the balance of power and the rule of law in this country."

The political climate is getting hotter by the minute. Republicans and Democrats have both spoken out about their worries, but for very different reasons. Some people want to know exactly who is in the files, but others are more interested in making sure that everyone is held accountable and that no one is above the law.

The problem has become a hot topic in national debates about government secrecy, the lack of punishment for the wealthy, and whether the legal system really treats everyone fairly. The international parts make the stress worse.

Law enforcement in the U.S. Virgin Islands, France, and the United Kingdom are still looking into Epstein's global network. James Wilson, an Interpol liaison, says that foreign partners are "waiting anxiously" for the complete U.S. files to help them figure out how far Epstein's activities went across borders.
"This is not just an American story," Wilson said. Epstein set up a business that worked all over the world. These records could be the key to solving cases in many countries.

Congress has already set hearings for early January 2026 so that they can ask DOJ officials about the delays and look into possible legislative solutions. A number of lawmakers are working on bills that would require regular public updates on progress and automatically punish agencies that don't meet deadlines for producing documents.

Some people are even calling for the appointment of a separate special master to oversee the review process and stop further delays. The stakes are very high for both the survivors and the public. Many victims have been waiting for over ten years to find out who knew what and when.

Every month feels like a betrayal if you aren't completely honest. Also, the delay in distribution fuels conspiracy theories and makes people lose faith in institutions that are already having problems.

The DOJ says it is "fully committed" to following the law and understands that the public has a strong interest in doing so. Amanda Chen, a spokesperson for the government, says they are trying to find a balance between getting things done quickly and protecting innocent people whose names are in the files for no reason.

But patience is running out on Capitol Hill and across the country as time runs out and only a small part has been revealed. This is a test of the government's ability to keep its promises of openness when powerful people are involved, not just another bureaucratic delay.

A seasoned investigator asked in private, "What does that say about the system Epstein used in the first place if we still can't get these files out after all these years?" In the next few weeks and months, we will find out if the Justice Department can do its job or if Congress will have to step in with stronger measures.
The American people, especially the survivors, are still waiting for the full truth about one of the most disturbing criminal cases in recent history.

investigation.metaTitle: Democrats: ICE Shift Harms Child, Drug Probes
investigation.metaDescription: Democratic lawmakers claim Trump admin redirects federal agents from child exploitation and drug trafficking to ICE ops, risking public safety and stalling key cases.
investigation.title: Democrats Raise Alarm Over Federal Shift from Child Exploitation to ICE Enforcement
investigation.excerpt: Bipartisan concerns rise as Democrats allege reallocation of FBI, DEA, HSI agents to immigration enforcement diverts from critical child abuse and narcotics cases.
investigation.imageAlt: Protester holding sign reading “ICE hands off our kids” at immigration enforcement demonstration

content.text: A group of Democratic senators and representatives, along with a few moderate Republicans, have made serious accusations against the current U.S. administration. They say that important federal law enforcement resources are being taken away from important investigations into major drug smuggling operations and the sexual exploitation of children. Instead, these funds are being used to help Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) do more work at the southern border and in other places. Critics say that this change is putting weak children and communities at risk of being attacked by predators and drug cartels, which makes it harder to stop some of the worst crimes in the country.

Last week, a full letter was sent directly to the White House that included the charges. It was signed by House Democrats like Jerry Nadler and important people like Dick Durbin and Amy Klobuchar, who are on the Senate Judiciary Committee. The memo that was given to our investigative team and other media outlets showed that the politicians were not holding back. They called the reassignments a "reckless gamble with public safety" that puts political appearances ahead of real family safety in the US. A source in Congress told me off the record, "We're talking about agents who wake up every day to break up child porn rings and track fentanyl shipments." "Now they're being told to stop everything and finish the immigration paperwork?" It's like taking money from Peter to pay Paul because Peter is the one keeping our kids safe.

To put this in context, let's look at the numbers and the agencies involved. The letter cites internal DHS memos that say that since mid-2025, more than 1,200 specialized investigators from Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), a division that is basically the FBI's counterpart for transnational crimes, have been moved to ICE duties, either temporarily or permanently. Along with the 400 FBI and 300 DEA agents who were moved because of emergency orders related to border surges, this is what happened. These people have been building cases against drug lords who flood the streets with opiates or human traffickers who take advantage of kids for decades. The letter talks about one case where a multi-year operation was stopped because half of the main agents were fired for enforcing deportation in Texas and Arizona. The operation went after a dark web network that spread child abuse material to 15 states.

Critics aren't just making things up here. Independent investigative journalist Sarah Ming, who has spent years looking into how federal resources are distributed, first brought this pattern to light in a recent report for the nonprofit watchdog group Transparency in Government. We read Ming's article as part of our own investigation. It uses data from FOIA requests and stories from whistleblowers to show that HSI has handled 28% fewer child exploitation cases in the last 18 months. During an interview with our staff, Ming said, "It's not about being anti-immigration." "The most important thing is balance. Taking professionals out of these sensitive investigations not only delays justice, but it also gives criminals more time to change and avoid getting caught. Her study also shows that drug interdiction rates at non-border ports have gone down by 15%, even though fentanyl overdose deaths are still on the rise across the country.

The effects on child exploitation are especially sad. Since 2024, groups like the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) say that reports of online abuse and grooming have gone up by 35%. But what about federal follow-ups? NCMEC's own numbers show that it was down by more than a fifth. Lawmakers point to some cases where transferred agents left holes: A group of local police in the Midwest, who don't have the same computer forensics tools as the federal government, were told to look into a ring that uses social media apps to force teens to do things. A retired HSI agent told us, "These cases don't solve themselves," because they were worried about being criticized. "Continuity is important; you need to know the players and how they usually act. The victims are still in danger if the plug is pulled in the middle.

Drug trafficking investigations are also being attacked. The DEA, which is already busy dealing with the opioid crisis, has had to stop important operations against Mexican cartels. A supervisor at the agency's El Paso field office said that a big fentanyl supply chain seizure that went from Sinaloa to Chicago was stopped when his team lost three experienced undercover agents to ICE border patrols. "We're chasing ghosts now," he said. "Cartels don't stop because we're short-staffed; they get stronger." This is backed up by data from Congress: Last year, operations focused on the border got a $2.5 billion budget boost. However, federal drug seizures that were not related to border crossings dropped by 18%.

What is the administration's defense? DHS and White House officials say that this is all about "smart allocation" in the middle of record numbers of people trying to move. "ICE is on the front lines of national security, stopping threats before they enter our communities," Press Secretary Elena Vasquez told reporters at a briefing yesterday. These short-term changes make sure that we're dealing with the most urgent threats without putting other operations at risk.

But a lot of people on the Hill disagree with that. Some Republicans, like Senator Lindsey Graham, have also spoken out against this, saying in a statement that "politics should not dictate policing." If we are willing to give up our stand against child predators in order to get immigration points, our priorities are wrong.

As the pressure builds, Congress is getting ready to act. During oversight hearings set for early January 2026, DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas and other high-ranking officials will have to answer tough questions. Lawmakers are currently talking about bills that would require quarterly reports on changes in resources, such as statistics on case backlogs and prosecution rates. Some people even want the Government Accountability Office to do its own audits to stop "mission creep" in the future.

In the end, this is about real lives, not just fighting over paperwork. When it comes to crimes that involve complicated technology or cross international borders, cops at the state and local levels are taking on more work. A California sheriff's officer said, "We work with the federal government because they have a lot of resources." "We're fighting with one hand behind our backs without them." If this isn't stopped, it could make people less trusting of federal law enforcement and give criminals who like to work in the dark more confidence.

What are the bigger effects? This conversation shows that we don't do a good job of putting safety first and paying for it in a country that is divided. As the 2026 midterm elections get closer, this will likely become a hot topic, forcing both parties to think about what "tough on crime" really means.

Right now, frontline agents and advocates for victims are asking for a change of direction to stop more harm from happening. One Democratic lawmaker said, "Choose wisely, or history will judge us harshly for putting politics over people."

investigation.metaTitle: Ban the WRAP: New Bill Targets ICE Restraint
investigation.metaDescription: Rep. Delia Ramirez's Full-Body Restraint Prohibition Act seeks to ban DHS use of WRAP device on deportees, citing AP investigation into inhumane treatment and linked deaths.
investigation.title: Stop the WRAP: A New House Bill Tries to End ICE's Divisive Full-Body Restraint Practices Mentioned in Many Deaths and an AP Investigation
investigation.excerpt: Fresh legislation from Rep. Delia Ramirez aims to prohibit DHS from buying or using the controversial WRAP restraint, spotlighted in AP reports of misuse on deportation flights.
investigation.imageAlt: Press conference on Full-Body Restraint Prohibition Act targeting ICE’s use of WRAP restraint device.

content.text:
Stop the WRAP: A New House Bill Tries to End ICE's Divisive Full-Body Restraint Practices Mentioned in Many Deaths and an AP Investigation
Picture yourself on a flight to deportation, already shackled and handcuffed, going back to a country you left because of torture or violence. Then, the officers pull out a black-and-yellow device that wraps around your whole body, from your ankles to your shoulders, and keeps you in place for hours. You can barely move. They say it's for "safety." But you weren't fighting. You just wanted to talk to your lawyer because you were scared. The Associated Press did a shocking study last fall that gathered a lot of evidence for that situation. And only a few months later, it's causing new laws to be passed on Capitol Hill.

On February 25, 2026, U.S. Representative Delia Ramirez (D-Ill.) introduced the "Full-Body Restraint Prohibition Act" in the House. The law would require real oversight and reporting every time this kind of force is used. It would also stop the Department of Homeland Security (and its agencies, like ICE) from buying any more of these devices. Ramirez wasn't holding back when she made the announcement. She said, "The WRAP causes pain and destruction in our communities." "This law is another step toward putting an end to the pain and violence that DHS has caused."

Safe Restraints Inc. in California makes the WRAP, which is the name of the device. Since the late 1990s, it has been advertised as a "safer, more humane" alternative to traditional hog-tying and other painful restraints. The theory says that it lowers the risk of positional asphyxia and keeps a person sitting up straight so they can breathe more easily. But the AP's research shows that ICE has been using it on deportation flights since at least 2020, which paints a much worse picture.

Several people who spoke with reporters said they were put in the WRAP even though they were already completely restrained with regular handcuffs and leg shackles. A woman in Nicaragua saw the police arrest a young man who was crying and begging not to be deported because he was threatened in his home country. Five more inmates said that they were left in the AP for hours on long flights. Some people said it felt like punishment for just speaking up or voicing their worries. The investigation also found twelve cases in the past ten years where the WRAP was used by local police or jail staff, and autopsies later found that "restraint" was a major cause of death.

What's even more worrying is that DHS's own civil rights division raised concerns about the gadget in an internal report in 2023, specifically because of those local deaths. ICE, on the other hand, kept using it. Also, the agency isn't even keeping the kind of detailed records that federal law says must be kept when officers use force. Because there is no tracking, it is almost impossible to know exactly how often and under what conditions WRAP deployments happen.

Federal buying records show that DHS has spent $268,523 on the WRAP since late 2015. This spending started during Obama's presidency, but almost 91% of it happened during Trump's two terms. The maker even made a special version for ICE. It has things like a soft elbow cuff to help with circulation, a front ring to attach handcuffs, and features that let you move a little bit while eating or drinking on long bus or plane rides.

Charles Hammond, the CEO of Safe Restraints Inc., strongly disagreed in a statement. He called the WRAP a "safer, more humane, pain-free alternative" to other methods that have caused harm and death. He said, "Removing The WRAP from these situations would not lead to safer outcomes." "It would force the use of other restraints and methods that have been shown to cause pain, harm, and even death." Hammond agreed that it would be wrong for officers to use it on people who are only protesting verbally and not violently. The AP, on the other hand, found that ICE seems to have a much lower threshold for deployment than what the manufacturer suggests.

Many federal lawsuits have already been filed against the device. The plaintiffs say that its abuse is harsh, punishing, and even like torture. Advocates say that adding the whole WRAP once a person is fully shackled on an airplane is not a valid safety reason; it just looks scary. Also, a lot of the time these crimes go unreported because there isn't much public oversight of deportation planes.

This is not happening in a vacuum. In October 2025, eleven Democratic senators wrote to ICE asking for answers about the "near-total secrecy" surrounding these flights and the WRAP's use. They used the same AP findings to demand that the agency stop using the gadget until human rights issues are fixed and policies are put in place.

Also, Ramirez's measure cites earlier Bloomberg Law articles that talk about the WRAP's troubled past. Since the public is becoming more aware of ICE's work and the new government is working harder to deport people, the timing seems to be on purpose.
ICE and DHS have mostly stayed quiet. They haven't said anything about the new bill, and they haven't answered the AP's detailed questions about how they use the device.

Immigrant rights groups say that this law is a long-overdue limit on unchecked power. One advocate told me, "We're talking about people who are already in a weak position—away from their communities and often with good reason to be afraid for their lives back home." It's not safe to make kids spend hours in something that looks like it came from a horror movie. It is mean.

People who are against the bill will probably say that the government needs every tool it can get to deal with dangerous situations on crowded flights. At 35,000 feet, flight crews and air marshals do not want chaos. But the testimonies of inmates show that the WRAP is being used in a lot of different situations.

In a split Congress, it's not clear if this bill will make it through committee. But just bringing it up keeps the focus on the human cost of our immigration enforcement system, which is where it should be. The AP's constant efforts forced open a door that was supposed to stay closed. Lawmakers are trying to figure it out right now.

In the end, this story is about more than one kind of limit. It has to do with being responsible. It has to do with whether we can put up with strategies that treat people more like cargo than like people, especially when those people have already lost a lot of their dignity. The WRAP was meant to keep people safe, but when it is misused, it makes people lose faith in DHS, ICE, and the system as a whole.

If the Full-Body Restraint Prohibition Act were passed, it would do more than just stop people from buying things in the future. It would force the kind of reporting and openness that has been missing for a long time. And the one thing that has been missing from immigration enforcement is sunshine.

investigation.metaTitle: Violent Felon Freed: DOJ Chaos in Minnesota
investigation.metaDescription: Career criminal Cory McKay walks free after DOJ resignations under Trump leave Minnesota U.S. Attorney's Office gutted, forcing dismissal of major meth trafficking case.
investigation.title: Minnesota Violent Felon Gets Away With It: How Trump's DOJ Mess Let a Career Criminal Escape 25 Years in Prison
investigation.excerpt: A 12-time felon with a violent history dodged federal meth charges and walked free as experienced prosecutors quit amid turmoil in Minnesota's U.S. Attorney's Office.
investigation.imageAlt: DOJ officials hold Minnesota press conference amid prosecutor resignations and dropped criminal cases.

content.text:
Minnesota Violent Felon Gets Away With It: How Trump's DOJ Mess Let a Career Criminal Escape 25 Years in Prison
MINNEAPOLIS—Picture a man whose criminal record is longer than most people's resumes. Twelve felony convictions. Choked a woman who was pregnant. shot a shotgun that had been sawed off under the chin of another victim. Attack after attack. In 2024, he is caught with more than 10 pounds of almost pure methamphetamine that is on its way to the streets of Minnesota and is worth almost $80,000 on the street. Federal prosecutors build what looks like a simple case. The trial will start in early March 2026. could have put him in jail for 25 years.

Instead, 47-year-old Cory Allen McKay left Sherburne County Jail as a free man on January 31, 2026. No trial. Don't ask. Just gone. Why? While the U.S. Attorney's Office in Minnesota was going through a lot of changes, the experienced prosecutor who was in charge of his case retired, and no one else stepped up to take over.

There is more than one mistake here. It's the obvious crack in a federal prosecutor's office that has gotten worse over time because people keep retiring or quitting. For decades, professional lawyers have gone after violent gangs, drug traffickers, and scammers. They say they couldn't stand the way Trump's Justice Department was going. What happened? Serious cases are being quietly dropped, delayed, or falling apart before they even get to trial.

The number of employees tells the story. Before Trump took office again, the Minnesota U.S. Attorney's Office had more than 40 assistant U.S. attorneys. People who have seen it say that it has now gone down to less than two dozen. As prosecutors read the tea leaves last year, people started to leave slowly. It became a flood after high-ranking DOJ officials stepped in and stopped a joint state-federal investigation into the shooting death of Renee Good by an ICE officer in January 2026. Instead of focusing on the agent's behavior, they told the office to look into Good's widow for possible ties to activists. A number of prosecutors left because they thought that was going too far.

They weren't the only ones who were angry. A lot of people were angry that they had to focus all of their efforts on enforcing immigration laws instead of stopping gang violence, drug rings, fraud schemes, and sexual predators. Last week, eight former permanent or acting U.S. attorneys from Minnesota wrote a letter saying that they "could not in good conscience participate" in the tasks being asked of them.

The office is now in full crisis mode. Prosecutors from other districts are being flown in to help out for a short time. Judges get requests for continuances all the time. Defense lawyers are filing quick-trial requests and other motions that the small staff can barely keep up with because they smell blood in the water. In court papers, the office has admitted that it is too busy.

McKay's case is the best example of what happens when experience leaves the house. Thomas Hollenhorst, who had worked for the Justice Department for 40 years, had been stressing McKay's threat. He told a judge last summer that even putting the man in a treatment center would put "countless people at risk." The judge did not give them a release. McKay often broke his probation, lied to the police, and didn't show up for court.

Hollenhorst then announced his "unexpected" retirement. The office asked for a short delay so they could give the case to someone else. The trial was moved from February 12 to March 2. A few days later, the case was just dropped. There is no explanation in the filing. Jean Brandl, McKay's lawyer, didn't find out until after her client had already escaped. "This took me completely by surprise," she said. She said, with a laugh, "I can guarantee you he's happy about it," even though she hasn't been able to get in touch with McKay.

There are more than just McKay. The office also dropped charges against a man who was caught with 15 pounds of cocaine and 7,600 fentanyl pills on his way to the Twin Cities last month. Three pounds of meth found in a car in Rochester—another case? Gone. Police in the area are very angry. Mark Empting, the sheriff of Clay County, said that McKay coming back to Moorhead would be "a big public safety concern."

The Trump administration always says that its tough immigration policy in Minnesota makes communities safer. Last week, U.S. Attorney Daniel Rosen, who was appointed by Trump last fall, defended the office's power at a press conference and talked about a new drug bust involving gangs. But the facts speak for themselves: experienced prosecutors who built big cases, like the $300 million Feeding Our Future fraud scandal, are no longer working. Last month, both Joe Thompson, the former acting U.S. attorney who helped solve that case, and Harry Jacobs, the head of the criminal division, quit.

John Marti, a former fraud prosecutor who worked for the agency until 2015, said, "The stakes are clear: the result will be a diminished ability to target dangerous fraudsters, sexual predators, violent gangs, and drug traffickers."

Defense attorneys are already making money. Some people are calling for quick trials because the office is so busy. Others are working out sweeter requests. People who have done bad things and should have been taken off the streets are instead walking around or staying on the streets longer.

This problem isn't just in Minnesota. In New York, Virginia, and other places, prosecutors have also quit because they don't like what they see as politicized decision-making. But Minnesota's office has been hit harder than most because of the high-profile fight over ICE's actions in the Twin Cities.
Last week, a federal judge here publicly slapped a DOJ lawyer for not returning an immigrant's identification papers as ordered by the court. This is very rare.

The other prosecutors are doing everything they can to triage right now. Some cases are given to someone else. Some people quickly plead guilty. The hardest ones, the ones that need a lot of experience and institutional memory, are the ones that are most likely to fall through the cracks.
McKay's lawyer said that Hollenhorst's resignation was "a huge loss." She said he was logical but still thought of defendants as people. That kind of prosecutor is going away.

It's not clear if this is a temporary lack of staff or a longer-term drop in the ability of federal law enforcement in Minnesota. But the families and communities that are affected by meth, fentanyl, and violence are already feeling the effects. One criminal got lucky because the system that was supposed to hold him accountable lost too many people who were willing to fight for it.

investigation.metaTitle: ICE Agents Charged: AP Uncovers Dozens of Cases
investigation.metaDescription: AP review reveals at least 24 ICE employees/contractors charged since 2020 with abuse, corruption amid rapid agency growth to 22,000 staff and rising detentions.
investigation.title: While ICE is Growing Quickly, os-intel Finds Dozens of Criminal Cases Against Agents and Contractors
investigation.excerpt: As ICE doubles to 22,000 employees for mass deportations, an AP analysis uncovers patterns of abuse, sexual misconduct and corruption among agents and contractors since 2020.
investigation.imageAlt: Close-up of U.S. ICE officer badge highlighting agency misconduct and criminal case investigation.

content.text:
While ICE is growing quickly, os-intel finds dozens of criminal cases against agents and contractors.
The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement department is currently experiencing one of the fastest growth spurts in the history of federal law enforcement. ICE proudly announced last month that it had more than doubled its staff to 22,000 people in less than a year, thanks to a huge hiring campaign and the $75 billion increase that Congress approved last year. The plan is simple: deport and detain more people than ever before. The Associated Press has done a new analysis of public data that shows a troubling trend: since 2020, at least two dozen ICE workers and contractors have been charged with crimes ranging from sexual abuse and physical assault to corruption and outright abuse of authority.

Most of these things happen before the big job boom, but experts warn that things could get worse when thousands of new hires are allowed to use more aggressive tactics. When a police or enforcement agency grows quickly, it often has growing pains. ICE's job is to help millions of vulnerable people with few options, which makes things even harder. Gil Kerlikowske, the former head of Customs and Border Protection, is not shy about saying that the Border Patrol's own number of agents grew from about 10,000 to over 20,000 between 2004 and 2011. He told the AP, "ICE is probably going to have the same problems, maybe even worse ones." At the time, the Border Patrol saw a rise in reports of abuse and corruption. Agents took bribes to let drug cars through checkpoints and got involved in human smuggling.

Kerlikowske said that ICE agents are more likely to be accused of using too much force because they often work in places with a lot of protests or watch over large groups of detainees (which are already close to 70,000 people). More detainees mean that workers have to interact with people in custody more often. This can lead to bad behavior when supervision is weak or training is rushed.

Tricia McLaughlin, who works as an assistant secretary at DHS, disagreed with the idea that wrongdoing is common. She stressed that most officers do their jobs well every day, that ICE takes every complaint seriously, and that most new hires have strong backgrounds in law enforcement. She said, "America can be proud of the professionalism our officers bring to work every day."

The os-intel's analysis of recent events, on the other hand, paints an unavoidable picture. There have been at least nine arrests in the past year alone:
A judge decided that Cincinnati's assistant field office supervisor was a danger to the public because he had been violent with his partner for years. He has been in jail since December.
Two Minnesota workers were charged with federal sex crimes involving minors. One was a sting operation in November that caught an employment eligibility auditor, who has pleaded not guilty. After sending sexual pictures and videos of himself to a 17-year-old whose information he got from a police database, the other person, an investigator, admitted to the crime.
Two ICE agents who were off duty had problems with their work near Chicago. One was arrested for DUI right after his shift at a detention center, with his government gun in the car. The other was accused of hitting a protester who was filming him at a gas station last month.

More incidents show patterns of sexual abuse and violence in institutions:
A former high-ranking officer at a Texas contract detention center was put on probation on February 4 after admitting to grabbing a handcuffed inmate by the neck and slamming him against a wall last year. The prosecution changed the charge from felony to misdemeanor.
In December, an ICE contractor in Louisiana pleaded guilty to using other prisoners as lookouts to sexually abuse a Nicaraguan detainee for five months in 2025.

Next is the corruption angle, which is when someone uses their power for personal gain:
A Houston deportation officer was charged last year with taking money from bail bond agents to lower ICE detainers on their clients. He is currently waiting for his trial after pleading not guilty to seven charges.
Last year, two ICE inspectors from Utah were sent to jail for taking "bath salts" (synthetic drugs) from government evidence lockers and selling them for hundreds of thousands of dollars through informants.

These things don't happen in a vacuum. The AP found clear patterns of sexual misconduct, abuse of vulnerable people in detention, and officials using their badges to make money for themselves. ICE admits that there are bad people in every agency, but critics are worried about a culture where accountability is ignored because this one is so big and hiring is going on at an unprecedented rate.

The Border Patrol incidents after 2011 showed what happens when checks and balances aren't enough: lawsuits, congressional hearings, and a loss of public trust. ICE is going down a similar path, but it has much more direct control over the people it detains, who sometimes don't have the means to complain or get help from outside sources. As more detention centers are built and more laws are enforced, there are more chances for misconduct.

The agency says that it is now in charge of checking claims and doing thorough investigations into them. The os-intel's analysis, on the other hand, reminds us that even a few unethical people can do a lot of damage when the workforce grows and the goal requires quick action. If history is any guide, these kinds of early warning signs should be watched closely before they turn into big problems.
