investigation.metaDescription: AP/Gecko investigation reveals senior officials enabled luxury homes in protected Western Area Peninsula National Park, threatening Freetown water and safety.
investigation.title: Officials Don't Care That Luxury Homes Are Being Built Illegally in Sierra Leone's Protected Park
investigation.excerpt: Powerful elites build lavish mansions inside Sierra Leone's key national park with official land titles, despite a suppressed government probe and ongoing risks to Freetown's water supply.
investigation.imageAlt: Illegal luxury homes under construction inside Sierra Leone’s Western Area Peninsula National Park.
keywords: Sierra Leone national park illegal construction

content.text:
Officials don't care that luxury homes are being built illegally in Sierra Leone's protected park.
As you drive south on the main road from the capital, you can see these beautiful white and cream-colored mansions. Some of them are still being built, with scaffolding and new concrete. These homes are not tiny. These huge luxury homes have walls that go up to the sky, swimming pools, and views of the ocean. They would cost millions of dollars anywhere else in the world. What's the problem? They are right in the middle of the Western Area Peninsula National Park, which is a protected rainforest that acts as both the water tower and the green lung for the two million people who live in Freetown.

According to a joint investigation by The Associated Press and The Gecko Project, senior government officials secretly gave out property titles and ignored the fact that at least 50 of these illegal homes were built on what was once dense jungle as recently as 2019. Construction is still going on, almost four years after President Julius Maada Bio asked for an official investigation into the matter.

The government's own investigation, which has never been made public before, lists names. It says that high-ranking officials, including one who is already a full cabinet minister, are to blame for the land seizures. Even though the report said that 17 people should be punished, not much has happened. Instead, one of the key players has been promoted.

This is more than just low-income families squatting on small plots of land because they need it. Bio Barray, the neighborhood at the center of the controversy, is home to the rich and powerful. Mayor Yvonne Aki-Sawyerr, a well-known environmentalist who is likely to run against Bio in the next presidential election, didn't hold back when she talked to investigators. "They are just being given permission," she said. "The government knows exactly what's going on."

Freetown is in between these tall, wooded hills and the Atlantic Ocean. The park feeds the reservoir that supplies 90% of the drinking water in the capital. It has also kept the city safe from flooding and landslides for many years. But the hills have been attacked. Miners, charcoal burners, cannabis growers, and now luxury developers have all cut down the trees. According to AP's analysis of satellite images, the Bio Barray houses are carved into the park's boundaries, right above the important reservoir.

The government's own inspectors warned that Freetown would face a "water shortage crisis" because of ongoing building and deforestation. They also said that deadly landslides were becoming more likely. In 2017, a huge slide on the edge of the park killed more than 1,000 people in one night. It was one of the deadliest natural disasters in Sierra Leone's history. The fire in 2022 that burned the slopes next to the reservoir finally made President Bio start the investigation.

The chief minister got the report in September 2022. A year later, the president's office released a carefully worded photo of Bio getting the results. He promised to do something about the "high places" that caused the damage. He said at the time, "We will do something very soon."

The mansions, on the other hand, are still there. Since that promise, walls have been built and new foundations have been laid. When AP reporters went to the site last year, they could see construction workers working on a number of properties. The builders told them that no one would stop the work because the owners were "big people."

One name stands out in the report that was not released: a high-ranking official who was involved in making illegal land deals possible. We tried to get a comment from the same person, who is now the Minister of Works and Public Assets, several times but got no response. When asked about the claims, David Sengeh, the current chief minister, said that the government doesn't act on "accusations only."

Opposition leaders and environmentalists see this as the worst case of elite impunity in a country that is still plagued by bad government and corruption. The park was supposed to be safe. The government has been working hard to get it recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site because of its unique biodiversity and role as a climate buffer. But inside its borders, luxurious homes for the rich and well-connected keep going up, while the people who live there have to deal with water shortages and live in fear of the next landslide.

This is especially annoying because of when it happened. Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world. It mostly depends on help from other countries and is still recovering from the civil war and the Ebola outbreak. The national park is one of the few natural beauties left in the area. Not only is it illegal to turn parts of it into a private playground for the rich, but doing so puts the capital's future at risk.

Mayor Aki-Sawyerr has been one of the most vocal supporters of enforcement. She says that the rich people who live in Bio Barray have been given rights that the average Sierra Leonean could never hope to have. "They are allowed to break the law because of who they are," she told the AP.

The government investigation suggested real punishments, such as fines, demolitions, and disciplinary action against the officials who were involved. Almost four years later, the houses are still standing, and at least one of the officials mentioned has been promoted to a higher position.

Satellite data shows that construction has not slowed down. After the study was supposedly sent to the highest levels of government, a number of new buildings appeared. The proof is even clearer on the ground: walls that have just been painted, roofs that are done, and security guards watching over properties that shouldn't be there.

The people of Freetown have more to lose than ever. Their water comes from that reservoir. To keep them safe, those wooded slopes must stay where they are. Every new illegal mansion weakens both of them.

President Bio's government has talked a lot about growth and fighting corruption. But in Bio Barray, the actions—or lack of them—tell a different story. A story about how some people in Sierra Leone really do get away with breaking the law, even though the law is supposed to protect the country's most valuable natural resources.
The mansions keep getting bigger. The trees keep falling. And as the powerful enjoy their view, the report that was supposed to end it all sits there, gathering dust.
